title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
this is a terrible idea. The underlying logic of this proposal is that, 1) all federal employees, no matter where they are located or what they do, must first and foremost be loyal to the President. This is, of course, patently ridiculous. 2) It implies that anyone can do any Federal employee's job; there is no requirement for institutional knowledge or specialization, or years of experience. This, too, is patently ridiculous. Federal employees hold positions ranging from lower-level (security guards and janitors, for example) to highly educated and experienced roles (research scientists and administrators). In any of these roles, Federal employees need to first perform the duties of the position to the level expected in their performance documents. As part of that review process, they should not be working against the government, no matter who the President is at the time. However, allegiance to that President above all else, as implied here, is UNAMERICAN and ACONSITUIONAL.

If implemented, it would move us further into authoritarianism with Federal employees whose allegiance, rather than skill, earns them employment. It would weaken services and disrupt our national security. None of this improves Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service; rather, it would destroy the Civil Service.

comment: The Schedule F/Policy and Career reclassification plans outlined in this new regulation, Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service, do not achieve the goals outlined in the regulations. 1) The policy categories as defined (policy advocating, influencing) apply to literally the entire government workforce, and therefore, it becomes a lottery of who is selected for this reclassification. title: Comment from Catherine Carter
comment:
I am absolutely appalled by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM)'s proposal of a new rule ("Schedule F" or " "Schedule Policy/Career") that will reclassify 50,000 federal workers as "at will" employees, making it easier to fire them for political reasons like expressing any kind of disagreement with the executive branch (public or personal) or adhering to the rule of law rather than the whim of an executive. This is a hatchet job on hard-working public servants, with the end goal of removing anyone who has the seniority, know-how, and will to resist illegal executive overreach.  

But you already know that, don't you? That's why it's happening.

I utterly oppose this proposed new rule; I call for the OPM to withdraw it and, instead, make some attempt to follow existing legal and procedural guidelines for classifying--and, when necessary but ONLY when necessary, removing--federal employees.

title: Comment from Michael Ore
comment:
I'm very concerned about any loosening of job protections that would enable undue pressure to career civil servants follow the whims of relatively short-lived 4-year presidential administrations. There's been a dangerous recent precedent of firings not due to job performance but rather failure to comply with illegal and/or unethical requests.

To a lesser extent, I'm also concerned about the soundness of financially motivated firing decisions, including layoffs in revenue-generating roles such as in the IRS. These decisions currently need more review and process, not less.

title: Comment from Pamela Elders
comment:
I object to OPM's proposed new rule that would reclassify 50,000 federal workers to "at-will" employees. "At-will" employment will make it easier to fire any employee for political rather than merit-based reasons. Under "at-will" employment, no reason is required for termination. And, there is little recourse for appeal. 

US civil servants are not political appointees and as such are not subject to removal by Presidential authority. The Civil Service was established to create a professional, non-partisan workforce rather than one based on cronyism. Fealty to the President and his agenda should never be a condition of civil service employment and yet, this is exactly what this proposed regulation seeks to establish. The regulation authors say the reclassification will make it easier to fire employees for "intentionally subverting Presidential directives." This is moving our government further in the direction of a dictatorship. title: Comment from Miles Ingram
comment: It is critical to evaluate this proposed rule in the larger context of the current Executive Branch efforts to erode the fair and objective administration of government, and turn the federal bureaucracy into a political tool for rewarding allies and punishing enemies of the current President. It is nothing short of a theft of the entire Executive branch from an institution that belongs to the American public to one that belongs to one man alone—Donald Trump. This rule is one part of a larger project to do what our founders most feared—turn the President into a king. To ignore this context and consider only the narrow technicalities of the proposal would either be willful blindness or purposeful manipulation of the rule-making process by those who naively and selfishly believe they will receive some favor from the would-be king. Nearly 250 years of American democracy are on the line.

title: Comment from Peter Sokol-Hessner
comment: Converting scientific positions into political appointees makes no more sense that hiring firefighters, waiters, or plumbers because of their favorite color - it's irrelevant and can have only one possible effect on science: it will hinder progress and waste money (because appointees will spend tax dollars on poorly-conceived, outdated, impossible, or already-addressed scientific directions). The US is a world-leader in science - everyone agrees that we lead the way in nearly all domains. That dominance is due to continued, long term smart investment in science and scientists. Political appointees in this domain would constitute a shockingly wasteful and partisan change. Because science touches all our lives in terms of medicine, business, policy, agriculture, policing, technology, weather, immigration, the economy, and so much more, this will quite literally eventually cost lives. Political appointees do not belong at the NSF.

comment: I oppose schedule F chiefly because science in the United States should be free from political interference. While science can guide policy making, policy goals should never guide science. This would not only be a disservice to the American people, but it would destroy the United States' reputation as THE global leader in biomedical discovery and innovation.

title: Comment from Martha Frommelt
comment:
I am submitting a commentary on the Office of Personnel Management, Docket ID: )PM-2025-0004/RIN 3206-AO801.

Keeping our civil service non-partisan is essential for running our government.  Re-classifying federal worker categories undermines this non-partisan approach and will lead to chaos, brain/experience drain, delays in work flows and more every time there is a new president.  Our continuous improvement as a government and country depends on keeping politics out of the work.  The work should be focused on how to best deliver the service, even if that means civil servants have to offer differing options and approaches that are currently in political favor.  In addition, civil servants need to complete their mission without fear of political reprisals.

Do not reclassify federal worker categories.

title: Comment from Judith Mitchell
comment:
I am a private individual strongly opposing the Office of Personnel Management’s proposed regulation – [Docket ID OPM-2025-0004] RIN 3206-AO80.

The stated reason for the proposed rule is to “allow agencies to quickly remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct, perform poorly, or . . .  intentionally [subvert] Presidential directives.”  (Summary 90 FR 17182)  However, this appears to be a thinly disguised effort to impose a “loyalty to President Trump test” for federal employees and fire those employees who are considered not sufficiently loyal to the President.  

The proposed rule may give “lip service” to the E.O. 14171 “directive” that an employee is “not required to pledge personal loyalty to the President or his policies” (Section 213.3501  90 FR 17201), however, if that employee is classified as “at will” and is fired because, for example, he or she is registered to a political party other than the one currently in office, how does that employee fight that wrongful termination?

The Summary states that “[a]gency supervisors report great difficulty removing employees for poor performance or misconduct.” (Summary 90 FR 17182).  There is no cite supporting that assertion.  And while making the process easier for supervisors to take adverse actions for employee misconduct may be a worthwhile objective, reclassifying employees in order to strip them of employees’ appeal rights is not logical and from what I have read may not be lawful. The December 2016 publication “Addressing Misconduct in the Federal Civil Service: Management Perspectives”  states at page 3: 

“Ultimately, what the survey data indicate is that there is some disagreement among supervisors about how many rights the system should provide to employees, including the desired extent of appeal and grievance rights. But, there is little disagreement on one crucial point – supervisors overwhelmingly want a merit-based system where employees are protected from managers who either make mistakes or act in bad faith. “
https://www.mspb.gov/studies/researchbriefs/Addressing_Misconduct_in_the_Federal_Civil_Service_Management_Perspectives_1363799.pdf   

The proposed rule does not address the problem of underperforming employees.  Quoting from the OPM Rule “Upholding Civil Service Protections and Merit System Principles”  [Docket ID: OPM-2023-0013]  RIN 3206-AO56 :

“[T]he characteristics of an employee's job—including whether the employee works on policy—has nothing to do with an employee's performance. Schedule F sought to streamline terminations based on the type of work that an employee performs, not based on how well the employee performs. It is therefore difficult to understand how Schedule F can be reconciled with its purported aim of addressing poor performance.”  89 FR 24995

In my opinion it is not “difficult to understand” how reclassification addresses poor performance, it makes no rational sense whatsoever.  

I am 74 years old and retired.  I receive Social Security based on my 40 years of work and rely on Medicare for health insurance coverage.  It is very important to me that the Social Security Administration employs reliable, knowledgeable employees and that human beings in the office are accessible by telephone, in person and online.  

I have always paid my taxes and believe that it is a responsibility of everyone who lives in this country to pay his or her fair share of taxes.  I rely on the Internal Revenue Service to promptly review my annual returns and promptly issue whatever refund I may be entitled to.  It is important to me that the I.R.S. be fully staffed with reliable, knowledgeable employees.

As I age, I recognize more and more how important scientific and medical research is for the health of my children and grandchildren.   My family and I will be adversely affected if research is slowed into preventative and curative therapies for respiratory viruses and infections, stroke recovery, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and other diseases and conditions that directly impact my life.  I rely on the Department of Health and Human Resources to be fully staffed with reliable and knowledgeable employees.

I do not trust that the proposed rule will improve the delivery of services by expert and experienced employees.  I believe it will greatly reduce the quality of services (paid for with our taxes) provided by federal agencies.

The stated reason for the proposed rule is to “allow agencies to quickly remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct, perform poorly, or . . .  intentionally [subvert] Presidential directives.”  (Summary 90 FR 17182)  However, this appears to be a thinly disguised effort to impose a “loyalty to President Trump test” for federal employees and fire those employees who are considered not sufficiently loyal to the President.  

The proposed rule may give “lip service” to the E.O. 14171 “directive” that an employee is “not required to pledge personal loyalty to the President or his policies” (Section 213.3501  90 FR 17201), however, if that employee is classified as “at will” and is fired because, for example, he or she is registered to a political party other than the one currently in office, how does that employee fight that wrongful termination?

The Summary states that “[a]gency supervisors report great difficulty removing employees for poor performance or misconduct.” (Summary 90 FR 17182).  There is no cite supporting that assertion.  And while making the process easier for supervisors to take adverse actions for employee misconduct may be a worthwhile objective, reclassifying employees in order to strip them of employees’ appeal rights is not logical and from what I have read may not be lawful. The December 2016 publication “Addressing Misconduct in the Federal Civil Service: Management Perspectives”  states at page 3: 

“Ultimately, what the survey data indicate is that there is some disagreement among supervisors about how many rights the system should provide to employees, including the desired extent of appeal and grievance rights. But, there is little disagreement on one crucial point – supervisors overwhelmingly want a merit-based system where employees are protected from managers who either make mistakes or act in bad faith. “
https://www.mspb.gov/studies/researchbriefs/Addressing_Misconduct_in_the_Federal_Civil_Service_Management_Perspectives_1363799.pdf   

The proposed rule does not address the problem of underperforming employees.  Quoting from the OPM Rule “Upholding Civil Service Protections and Merit System Principles”  [Docket ID: OPM-2023-0013]  RIN 3206-AO56 :

“[T]he characteristics of an employee's job—including whether the employee works on policy—has nothing to do with an employee's performance. Schedule F sought to streamline terminations based on the type of work that an employee performs, not based on how well the employee performs. It is therefore difficult to understand how Schedule F can be reconciled with its purported aim of addressing poor performance.”  89 FR 24995

In my opinion it is not “difficult to understand” how reclassification addresses poor performance, it makes no rational sense whatsoever.  

I am 74 years old and retired.  I receive Social Security based on my 40 years of work and rely on Medicare for health insurance coverage.  It is very important to me that the Social Security Administration employs reliable, knowledgeable employees and that human beings in the office are accessible by telephone, in person and online.  

I have always paid my taxes and believe that it is a responsibility of everyone who lives in this country to pay his or her fair share of taxes.  I rely on the Internal Revenue Service to promptly review my annual returns and promptly issue whatever refund I may be entitled to.  It is important to me that the I.R.S. be fully staffed with reliable, knowledgeable employees.

As I age, I recognize more and more how important scientific and medical research is for the health of my children and grandchildren.   My family and I will be adversely affected if research is slowed into preventative and curative therapies for respiratory viruses and infections, stroke recovery, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and other diseases and conditions that directly impact my life.  I rely on the Department of Health and Human Resources to be fully staffed with reliable and knowledgeable employees.

I do not trust that the proposed rule will improve the delivery of services by expert and experienced employees.  I believe it will greatly reduce the quality of services (paid for with our taxes) provided by federal agencies.

rationale: The comment expresses strong opposition to the proposed rule, highlighting concerns about politicization and the potential erosion of due process rights for federal employees, particularly regarding loyalty to the President.
themes: Due process/employee rights, Politicization concerns

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am writing to express strong opposition to the Office of Personnel Management’s (OPM) proposed rule OPM-2025-0004-0001, which seeks to reclassify approximately 50,000 federal employees into a newly designated Schedule Policy/Career (P/C) category. This proposal, a revival of the previously rescinded Schedule F, threatens the foundational principles of a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service and poses significant risks to the integrity, efficiency, and accountability of federal operations.

All Federal Agencies rely on the continuity that apolitical civil servants provide.  They swear an oath to uphold the Constitution, not any one elected official, and it should be that way.  Their job is to carry out policies for the current administration within the bounds of the law.  Current job protections are in place to see that employees are removed for performance causes, not ideological cause.

title: Comment from Alexander Tsai
comment:
Comment on Proposed Rule: "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" (Docket Number: RIN 3206-AO72)

Introduction

I am submitting this comment as an academic physician-scientist with more than a decade of experience conducting NIH-funded research at Massachusetts General Hospital with appointments at Harvard Medical School and Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. As a researcher with extensive experience in the NIH grant system, I am writing to express significant concerns regarding the section of the proposed rule that designates employees with "substantive participation and discretionary authority in agency grantmaking" as potentially occupying "policymaking positions" that could be reclassified under Schedule Policy/Career.

Specific Concerns with the Proposed Rule

The proposed rule identifies grant-making as "an important form of policymaking" and suggests that employees with "substantive discretionary role in how federal funding gets allocated may occupy policymaking positions." This characterization fundamentally misunderstands the scientific grant review process at agencies like NIH and NSF, which rely on scientific merit and peer review rather than political considerations.

The stated purpose of this rule is to allow agencies to "quickly remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct, perform poorly, or undermine the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives." When applied to scientific grant-making, this creates a dangerous framework that could politicize what should be an independent, merit-based process.

Evidence-Based Arguments

The primacy of American scientific research in the world depends on insulating technical grant review from political influence:

1. NIH and NSF grant review processes are designed to fund the most scientifically promising research through rigorous peer review. The NIH is "arguably the most important institution shaping the rate and direction of scientific research" with significant implications for human well-being. Even small changes to how funding is allocated could have massive effects on social welfare.

2. International examples demonstrate the severe consequences when politics interferes with scientific funding decisions. Soviet biology, which had achieved peak prominence by the mid-1930s, was essentially ruined by Lysenko's politically-backed campaign against genetics (Ptushenko, Genetics, 2021). The damage was so profound that even after Lysenkoism was officially renounced in 1964, it took decades for Russian science to recover from this political interference.

3. Similarly, in countries like China where "personal relationships have affected government decisions, such as the review of scientific grants," scientific integrity issues have damaged progress despite massive investments (Zeng et al. Dev World Bioeth, 2010). Studies indicate that politicization of science funding leads to inefficient allocation of resources, limiting China's ability to achieve global scientific leadership commensurate with its spending (Shu et al. Minerva, 2022; Yu et al. Res Policy, 2022).

4. The existing peer review system, while imperfect, provides important guardrails against bias. These decisions should be made by scientific experts, not political appointees.

Specific Recommendations for Improvement

I propose the following improvements to the rule:

1. Explicitly exclude scientific grant review personnel at NIH, NSF, and similar research agencies from the Schedule Policy/Career designation. Scientific merit review is a technical function, not a political one.

2. Provide a clear, narrow definition of what constitutes "substantive discretionary authority" in grant-making that distinguishes between technical evaluation based on scientific merit (which should remain protected) and truly discretionary policy decisions.

3. Add specific safeguards ensuring the independence of scientific peer review committees from political interference, including explicit protections for review panel members.

4. Require transparency in any actions that would redesignate positions related to scientific grant review, including advance notice and comment periods specific to each affected role.

Conclusion

While improving accountability in government service is a worthwhile goal, applying at-will employment status to scientific grant-making personnel poses significant risks to American scientific leadership. The independence of the scientific grant-making process from political influence has been a cornerstone of American research excellence and must be preserved.

title: Comment from Rachel F
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

This will undermine Americans' trust that our federal government is working for all of us, regardless of party and ideology.

Sincerley,

title: Comment from Richard Levy
comment:
I am writing to express my concerns with this proposed rule change. In short, I think the rule change would open the civil service up to political influence at the expense of carrying out the law and serving the American taxpayers. I am a federal employee yet these views are my own and do not necessarily represent my agency. I am writing as a concerned citizen and a student of good governance, on my own time.

1. The rule conflates issues around performance and conduct with those of allegiance to policy. From my experience, issues with performance revolve around doing work of poor quality, not adequately fulfilling or understanding the assignment, or otherwise acting in ways that do not serve the mission. Conduct issues concern things like consistently showing up to work late, taking excessive breaks, or acting uncooperatively with colleagues. Issues around not following allegiance to policy are another matter, and would concern things like failing to follow the law or a legal Presidential directive.

I'd like to see the evidence of staff not following laws or Presidential directives. From my experience, staff carry out laws and Presidential directives regardless of whether they agree; and if they don't, they switch jobs or quit on their own. For example, some staff at my agency did not agree with the Executive Order (https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/ending-radical-and-wasteful-government-dei-programs-and-preferencing/) which led to the taking down of materials that referenced Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. Among other factors, we did not see it as a good use of time. But my agency did it. Similarly, prior administrations have made requests of staff that they may have disagreed with, yet they were carried out.

Staff have been trained that if we have concerns, we comply, and then complain. Historically, staff have had the option of contacting the Office of Special Counsel or Inspectors General offices if they were concerned about waste, fraud, and abuse. As such, it has been disturbing these agencies had agency heads fired so early in the administration.

If staff are slow-walking or not carrying out directives now, it would behoove the administration to figure out why there has been a change in behavior. I think it's because this administration has represented a departure from legal or democratic ways of conducting government business. For example, various Executive Orders have directed actions which many consider illegal, such as shutting down federal agencies unilaterally, even though Congress has the legal right to pass laws to create or shut down agencies. It is especially troubling now because the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches are all led by the same party, so the administration is acting outside the legal system even when it ostensibly has the support it needs.

2. As for addressing poor performance and conduct, I find that agencies do not use a tool at their disposal which would make their lives much easier: Assigning another manager either to manage a poor performer (from my experience, such performers are rare), or assigning that manager to manage existing staff so the current manager can focus on the poor performer.

3. As it were, the civil service protections are admittedly a double-edged sword. The same protections which protect civil servants from undue political influence -- say, fabricating or withholding data to make an administration look better -- also serve to make it difficult to remove them. However, removing these protections makes any administration vulnerable to having the next administration come in and reverse them, thus catching the protection-removing administration in its own web. It would be short-sighted for any administration to remove these protections.

Thank you for your consideration of my comments.
Rich Levy

title: Comment from Corinne Scheman
comment:
I am writing to the OPM about the proposed reclassification of government workers to Schedule F: Docket ID OPM-2025-0004. Please do not do this.

I firmly believe that politicizing the civil workforce will harm our country. The US's civil workforce, independent FED, and ability to keep much of the government's work in capable, skilled, and nonpartisan hands have allowed the US to become an economic force, a well-respected leader, and a strong nation. Please do not destroy this by adding more political workers to the workforce. 

Our country needs an experienced and consistent workforce, not one that is changing with the current president. In our country, we do not have a president for life, we do not have an authoritarian leader,  and we do not have a considerable government workforce that changes every four or eight years. It is the consistency and experience that keep our government functioning well. At the very least, the reason should be that this president cannot fill all the existing political appointments; why add more? But that is not the reason that I am concerned about this proposed change in government workers. Please do not cause more instability in our country. 

Do not fire any more government workers. Do not reclassify any government workers. We are losing valuable expertise and skilled workers, gaining nothing in return. Do not add a Schedule F to the government. 

Thank you.
Corinne

title: Comment from Jeffrey Chenoweth
comment:
The proposed rule encompasses far more than the policy determining and policy-making roles it intends to target. The proposed rule incorrectly considers positions “held accountable for the success of one or more specific programs or projects” as having a policy-making or policy-determining nexus. While some projects and programs may be of a policy-influencing nature, the proposed test that a project or program lead is merely held accountable for the project or program success is insufficient to determine a policy nexus. For example, a project that installs new telecom equipment in an office building would be a project with no policy-making or policy-determining nexus, but under the pay for performance principles established for federal employees, the project manager would be held accountable for the cost, schedule and performance of the project.

Under the proposed rule, such employees would be considered for Schedule Policy/Career, despite not having a policy-influencing nexus. The proposed rule should be modified to ensure the tests determine the project or program are policy-influencing and not just that the project or program manager is held accountable for the program or project success.

title: Comment from Kira Swanson
comment:
To whom it may concern,
I am writing to oppose the proposed rule by the Office of Personnel Management on Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service. Recent federal actions against civil servants are not only deeply disrespectful to those who have dedicated years of service to our country, but are undermining the quality of life of citizens in our great nation. 
Agencies such as the National Park Service, the US Forest Service, Veterans Affairs, Natural Resources Conservation Service, Bureau of Land Management, US Army Corps of Engineers, Center for Disease Control, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, among many others, provide valuable services to manage our Nations resources and wellbeing. These agencies are invaluable and should continue to fulfill their important missions. In order to operate, these agencies need qualified and committed staff. Each of these agencies have Human Resource departments that manage staff performance through performance evaluations, improvement plans, and remedial actions as needed. No evidence has been provided that these Human Resource efforts are not working effectively.
The proposed rule appears to be a politized effort to further reduce the morale of staff in order to destabilize, shrink, and possibly eliminate these agencies. I strongly believe in the importance of these agencies. Furthermore, I believe in creating a work environment where workers are respected, fairly compensated, and supported so they can undertake the quality work that they do on behalf of our country. 
To summarize, I strongly appose the proposed rule on Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service.
Sincerely,
Kira Swanson

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The suggested policy change will have several major impacts on federal service;
1) Undermining first amendment rights of federal employees; their ability to register for political parties, engage in constitutionally-guaranteed free-speech activities, and potentially suppress the ability to participate in voting, for fear of punishment. If the intent is to ban federal employees for voting for presidential candidates, or to limit them to voting only for the incumbent, then this should be plainly noted and considered on its face.
1b) Changing employment status on the basis of political affiliation or beliefs is a violation of state/local law in multiple states, to include Washington, DC. To implement a federal policy such as this would override the rights of states to self-govern, and be an unnecessary and tedious limitation on the freedoms of citizens of those locales. Recommend at minimum limiting the policy change to locations where this would not create a conflict between federal policy and state/local law.

2) CBO analysis shows that on average public employees are paid less than private employees, with an average pay disparity of 24% (https://www.cbo.gov/publication/60235). This pay disparity is partially compensated for by the promise of secure benefits and relatively stable employment. In order to ensure a minimum level of quality service for the American public, should this policy change be approved, it must be paired with tying federal pay to more closely track the equivalent pays in private sector, ideally through an objective measure of pay overall, or by matching pay for similar fields. Inequality of pay has, similar to the limit of supervisory abilities to remove underperforming employees, been a significant concern for adequate staffing for many decades. Solving one issue without resolving the other will result in a significant negative impact to the ability to staff government with qualified and motivated employees.

I appreciate the thoughtful and robust research invested in the policy document in question, and hope the concerns regarding curtailing rights and undermining the basic pillars of effective manpower are resolved expeditiously.

title: Comment from Prathima Radhakrishnan
comment:
I am a scientist and a citizen who is interested in this regulation because I believe that the civil service plays an important role in our society in ensuring that the laws of the land are carried out properly. Specifically, in the context of science, I am someone who has a PhD that was funded, in part, by the National Institutes of Health. I believe that the National Institutes of Health is an institution that has played an enormous role in the success of this country, in allowing for monumental scientific discoveries to be made which are valuable on their own, in addition to contributing to the development of medication (I believe that over 99% of all drugs were developed based on information contained in an NIH funded study) and contributing to the economic activity of this country (I have seen a statistic that says that for every $1 invested into the NIH, the economy recovers $2.46). Therefore, it is important to me to ensure that the National Institutes of Health remains an organization that continues to fund excellent science, in addition to carrying out groundbreaking research within the institute itself.

I would like to comment on the part of this regulation removes protections from civil servants in order to make them easier to fire. I believe that this would be a grave mistake and am opposed to this change. I believe that allowing this change to go through would remove many nonpartisan experts from our federal agencies and would replace them with political appointees. In the context of the NIH, this would be disastrous because it would remove scientists who are renowned in their fields with decades of experience and replace them with political appointees who are interested in carrying out an ideological agenda, namely censorship of research and information that they believe is hostile to right wing causes. In the last months, we have seen the haphazard way in which the National Institutes of Health has terminated many active grants, in fields such as HIV, mRNA vaccines and more. The termination of vaccine-related grants is particularly troubling to me because the skepticism of mRNA vaccines is a result of right wing misinformation and is not based on solid research. I worry that if the NIH continues not to fund many promising areas of research in order to promote a political agenda, the discovery of cures for deadly diseases like cancer and Alzheimers will be delayed. 

Furthermore, science is a discipline that requires a lot of training and nuance and replacing experts with novices who are not equipped to make careful scientific decisions will harm the longterm prospects of this country. I know that the rule says that fired civil servants will be replaced with nonpartisans but all of the evidence I have seen so far, does not make me trust the administration when it comes to this statement. For example, the chief of staff of the NIH Director, a position that has always been held by a scientist was recently transferred to Seana Cranston, who is not a scientist but is instead a political operative who has worked with Representative Thomas Massie and Senator Rand Paul. Furthermore, the haphazard nature of the decisions made by the NIH under the Trump administration does not give me confidence that nonpartisan scientists who are fired will be replaced by skilled experts. For example, in an attemot to defund research which is "DEI", many important clinical trials testing drugs for diseases like Stage 4 breast cancer have been defunded, simply because they included an LGBTQ participant within the trial. We have also heard of the cancellation of research grants involving domestic partner violence, an issue which affects many women, but which the administration deemed "unnecessary" for a reason that is much more likely to be political rather than scientific. 

Lastly, I am worried that if the status of these civil servants changes to being at-will, then Trump administration officials will be able to fire these employees for speaking out against unlawful orders or acting as whistleblowers. This would severely reduce the autonomy of even nonpartisan experts to carry out their jobs and make decisions that are best for science, even if they are at odds with the wishes of the administration.

Therefore, it is my recommendation that these changes not go through and that civil service protections for civil servants remain in place. 

Thank you.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: Thank you for the opportunity to comment. Good managers can already document poor performers and have them removed with due process. This rule runs the risk of making the government workforce political. The last time it was mostly political was during the Harding Administration when there was rampant corruption. Hiring was changed to a merit-based system because of those scandals. Schedule F will mean the government will no longer be merit-based, and firings will happen if government workers don't close their eyes to corruption, misconduct, or reckless behavior of their superiors or peers. They may even be forced to participate in fear of being fired. In addition, there will be no long-term policy experience because government workers will change each Administration, and employees may also be too afraid to share their expertise and provide objective pros and cons of policies for decision-makers to consider. Employees generally seamlessly support new Administration's priorities but take their oath to the Constitution seriously - if it's legal, they will pivot accordingly; if it's not legal or if it's reckless, they will speak up on behalf of the American public. This is critical for transparency of the government and for the rule of law. Another point I want to make is that if one Administration creates a new office, another Administration can already easily move those employees and even have them do similar work supporting their own policies. Government workers already must choose between implementing new policies or leaving, unless they are asked to do something inappropriate in which case they should be able to freely speak. It's critical that the government workforce remain neutral and lawful and represent the public and the Constitution. Otherwise, there is the danger of a repeat of the Harding days with government employees working for political bosses rather than the American people. The lack of continuity in the workforce will be dangerous as well, especially since policies and procedures are often reinvented years later, and there will be no institutional knowledge of how to manage these changes or what the benefits and costs are. Whatever politicians decide, it's important that they have all the facts and are aware of the unintended consequences of policy changes.

title: Comment from Alexis  Gibson
comment:
Dear Office of Personnel Management:

I write to express my strong opposition to the proposed rule entitled "Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service", published on April 23, 2025. The proposal seeks to exempt a newly defined category of “Schedule Policy/Career” positions from the statutory protections of 5 U.S.C. Chapters 43 and 75, including the right to appeal adverse personnel actions to the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB). This proposal is inconsistent with governing federal statutes and exceeds the scope of executive authority.

1. Statutory Protections Cannot Be Waived by Regulation

Congress has clearly and intentionally established a legal framework that governs performance-based and adverse actions affecting federal employees. Under 5 U.S.C. §§ 4303 and 7513, covered employees are entitled to procedural protections, including advance notice, an opportunity to respond, and the ability to appeal to the MSPB. These protections were codified by the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA), which replaced earlier patchwork systems with a unified statutory framework. These rights are not discretionary, nor can they be modified or withdrawn by regulation.

While the statute (5 U.S.C. § 7511(b)(2)) allows for the exclusion of certain positions from Chapter 75, such as political appointees or positions designated as “confidential or policy-determining,” it does not authorize the wholesale transfer of career civil service employees into newly created at-will categories through regulatory action. The authority to exclude positions from Chapter 75 is limited in scope and purpose and must be interpreted narrowly to avoid undermining Congress’s express intent.

2. The Proposal Violates the Separation of Powers

By unilaterally removing procedural protections through the creation of the “Schedule Policy/Career” classification, the Executive Branch is attempting to do through regulation what Congress has expressly prohibited—removing career employees without just cause, due process, or meaningful appeal. This raises significant constitutional concerns under the separation of powers doctrine. The Executive cannot override or nullify Congressional enactments through rulemaking.

The U.S. Supreme Court has recognized that where Congress has created a comprehensive remedial scheme (as with the CSRA), judicial and administrative bodies must follow that framework. The proposed rule contradicts this well-established principle and risks subjecting the Executive Branch to legal challenge on administrative and constitutional grounds.

3. Undermining Merit System Principles

The proposed rule would have a chilling effect on the integrity and independence of the civil service. Career employees in policy-influencing roles—many of whom are technical experts or senior supervisors—would become vulnerable to arbitrary dismissal, political coercion, or reprisal for faithfully executing laws as enacted by Congress. This undermines 5 U.S.C. § 2301, which mandates that employees be retained based on performance and protected from arbitrary action and personal favoritism.

Removing these protections does not enhance accountability—it creates a workforce subject to political influence and fear, contrary to the principles that have guided the civil service for over a century.

Conclusion

For the reasons stated above, I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule in its entirety. The authority to alter statutory employee protections rests solely with Congress, and any attempt to circumvent that authority via regulation is unlawful and harmful to the public interest. I respectfully request that OPM reconsider this proposed rule in light of its legal and constitutional infirmities.

title: Comment from Anne DeVries
comment:
Framing grantmaking as policy via this regulatory approach will inevitably degrade the scientific rigor of established grant review processes.
Scientific grants should be evaluated by nonpartisan career civil servants with appropriate expertise and experience, dedicated to the long term mission of their agencies.

The rule indicates that all involved in all grantmaking are considered policymaking positions and that the President can dictate whether those individuals' actions are aligned with their policies -- no matter who the President is or their party affiliation. Those involved in grantmaking should be nonpartisan career civil servants with appropriate expertise and experience to write funding announcements, evaluate grant applications, and recommend grant funding to achieve the missions of their agencies. They should not have to live in fear that their positions would be at risk if their expert-driven, rigorous decision-making is not consistent with one person's opinions. Adoption of this Proposed Rule will have dire consequences on our country's ability to conduct the best research, educate the best trainees, build the best infrastructure, and provide the best services.

In general doing a wide sweep of so many civil servants into political appointments is wrong and takes us back to before the civil service rule was put in. It was terrible back before President Garfield!

title: Comment from Andrea Versenyi
comment:

title: Comment from Rebecca Klymkowsky
comment:
I oppose the proposed change related to Schedule F.
Reviving this classification threatens the core of our merit-based, nonpartisan civil service—a system that's worked for over a century.

Why it matters:
Schedule F undermines the Pendleton Act of 1883, which ended the spoils system and established merit-based hiring.
It allows wide reclassification and at-will removal of policy-focused civil servants—opening the door to political interference.

It violates federal law:
-5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8): Hiring must be apolitical.
-5 U.S.C. § 7513: Requires cause and due process for removal.
-5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq.: OPM must uphold merit principles—not erode them.

The risk:
-Chills dissent and expert advice inside agencies
-Weakens institutional knowledge
-Politicizes public service
-Damages program continuity between administrations

Bottom line: Schedule F isn’t reform—it’s regression. It endangers good governance, civil service independence, and rule of law.

I urge the administration and OPM to reject any attempt to implement or revive Schedule F.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I vehemently oppose the creation of Schedule F and the re-categorization of federal employees and civil servants into political appointees. While there are legitimate issues with the speed and efficacy of government employee reviews, this proposed change would turn civil servants into a fearful, closed-off, and vindictive authoritarian arm of every administration current or future. Civil service is supposed to serve ALL of the American public, not the personal desires of the president or a single political party, and once this line is crossed there is no turning back. Any administration could threaten employees and upend due process and the lawful execution of reviews and implementation of policy and law, summarily firing any opposition without due process or recourse.

The enforcement of employee standards through weaponized political directive will have a chilling effect on employees reporting harassment, illegal activity, or poor performance for fear of retribution - this proposal will not only have the opposite effect of it's stated purpose but encourage and enable corruption and unaccountability.

Examples given in the "Proposed Rule Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" fact sheet demonstrate intent to use this change for that very purpose, while using examples like as the FDIC sexual harassment case as a "gotcha" to make opposing this change appear to condone such behavior. Not only is such behavior reprehensible, it would be ENABLED by this rule change, which would remove review and appeals recourse for employees fired for reporting such activity by supervisors, etc.

I urge OPM to consider the precedent it is setting and the implications this drastic change will have during this AND future administrations, with the full implications and due weight of turning apolitical federal employees into a weaponized arm of power for any president.

In addition, 30 days is far too short a time frame to solicit comments for such a sweeping change - I strongly urge you to extend the comment period to a minimum of 120 days.

Schedule F would allow broad reclassification of career civil servants, particularly policy professionals, making them vulnerable to politically motivated hiring and firing. This violates core principles in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8) and due process protections in 5 U.S.C. § 7513.

Stripping thousands of employees of civil service protections erodes accountability, chills dissent, and weakens effective governance. It also contradicts the Office of Personnel Management’s statutory mission to uphold merit system principles under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq.

I urge the administration and OPM to reject any proposal that revives or implements schedule F.

title: Comment from Thomas Krueger
comment:
I write to oppose the proposed Schedule F classification. It seems to run contrary to our long history, and to a number of existing laws and regulations, that recognize how important a professional, stable, knowledgeable, non-partisan civil service is to a well-functioning government.  
This new proposal would violate the Civil Service Reform Act protections against arbitrary dismissal. The language and history of the CSRA provides only very narrow exceptions for positions of a “confidential or policy-determining character.” I do not understand how the unprecedentedly broad interpretation of the statutory language could be consistent with the statutory language, legislative history, or caselaw concerning this narrow exception to the CSRA's broad civil service protections. The proposed regulations remove this longstanding and important protection without justification or due process.

The Federal Register notice doesn't provide a reasoned explanation for these wide-ranging changes, doesn't describe how these changes were developed or how lines will be drawn, and doesn't reflect any input from, or consideration of, the employees who would be affected  It doesn't provide sufficient detail on how the changes would be implemented, or by whom.  

These new proposals specifically undermine recent properly promulgated regulations meant to assure that the federal civil service would not become a patronage system, sacrificing competence for political fealty. By removing civil service protections through the proposed Schedule F expansion, employees would also be deterred from reporting wrongdoing due to fear of retaliation, thereby weakening whistleblowing safeguards. This would remove a valuable mechanism for identifying and reporting waste, fraud, and abuse.

The proposed Schedule F classification violates established federal laws and constitutional protections, and circumvents the role of Congress. Its implementation could fundamentally alter the structure and integrity of the federal civil service, leading to increased politicization and diminished employee rights and protections.

I strongly urge that this proposal be withdrawn.

comment: I am writing to oppose OPMs new Scheduled/Policy Career Rule.     This will undermine the non partisan nature of the civil service and designate thousands of federal employees at “at will employees”. I am concerned about the cost of government but know from experience in the private sector that it is short sighted change large swaths of employees each time an administrator or administration is changed.  The institution loses the institutional knowledge that is necessary to carry on uninterrupted functioning and this type of turnover becomes extremely costly as highly trained employees will look to make stable environments for their career choices.   I am asking that the unintended consequences and the costs of these be clearly calculated and make transparent to the public before this type of rule change is implemented.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am contacting you regarding “Office of Personnel Management”) and “Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004” or “RIN 3206-AO80” .  Please kindly maintain the civil service protections from about 50,000 people — roughly 2% of the federal work force.  For the United States to continue to be a democracy, the federal work force cannot be answerable to any President.  They are employees of the citizens of the United States.  The federal work force has been effective at protecting Americans in many ways. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am commenting on OPM-2025-0004-0001

I oppose the proposal to include Schedule Policy/Career as an excepted service schedule.   This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.
 By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, this proposal allows politically motivated firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague criteria for classifying employees under this schedule and for firing employees who have been classified violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing the proposed schedule contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.
The change is being justified as increasing employee accountability, but this term is not defined.  The preamble suggests that this reclassification will address poor performers within government, but does not explain how the "at will" status limits firing to poor performers or how the rule will address poor performance in non-policy-making positions.  The rulemaking provides several examples of employees behaving badly, but doesn't explain why existing rules and laws are insufficient to address these problems. The current system does allow federal supervisors to both fire poor performing employees and to encourage them to seek work elsewhere.   
In summery this change is counter to statute and ill-advised.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I second this excellent comment by a fellow concerned citizen. I, like most loyal Americans, am appalled by the proposed to politicize the civil service and return to the days of the spoils system.

"Schedule F should be limited to those that have the authority to change policy, not the people who draft, edit, or implement policy. Merit based civil service provides competent, professional civil servants regardless of administration. Removing those protections will not create a more efficient or effective government and will increase the political volatility, abuse, and corruption in the federal government.

I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

title: Comment from Sarah McTavish
comment:
I write in strong opposition to the "Schedule F" classification as it threatens the merit-based civil service system that the nonpartisan federal workforce has been built upon for over a hundred years. The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883 was specifically enacted to make the move from a spoils system to the current merit-based practice we have today. Reclassifying employees as Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated career actions, which flies in the face of the principles of a nonpartisan federal workforce. Specifically, I reference 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires federal employment decisions to be based on MERIT and be free from political influence. Given this administration's emphasis on merit-based hiring, Schedule F seems antithetical to its own priorities.

Additionally, the broad criteria used for the classification of an employee under Schedule F would also violate due process protections for career federal employees guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513. Furthermore, OPM is bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit-based civil service system principles. Enacting Schedule F runs contradictory to this statute and places political pressure on career employees, undermining the integrity and continuity of federal programs across changing administrations. 

Schedule F represents a substantive threat to no only civil service independence, but the law itself. I strongly encourage this administration to review the relevant statutes and laws and reject any regulatory framework that seeks to skirt these codified protections of a merit-based system.

title: Comment from Jesse  Canchola
comment:
To: Office of Personnel Management
Re: Docket ID OPM–2025–0004 – Proposed Rule: Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service
Date: 25 April 2025

Dear Office of Personnel Management,

I write in strong opposition to the proposed rule (OPM–2025–0004) that would reclassify federal scientists, statisticians, and other technical experts into the newly created “Schedule Policy/Career” (formerly Schedule F) category, eliminating their long-standing civil service protections.
As a Principal Statistician at StatCon Consulting, with over 30 years of experience in biostatistics and data science across academia, industry, and government collaborations, I am deeply alarmed that this rule would make thousands of federal employees at-will—stripping them of due process protections that are foundational to a professional, nonpartisan civil service.

Federal scientists and statisticians play a critical role in ensuring that government policies are grounded in sound, unbiased evidence. Their work touches every aspect of American life—from public health, economic indicators, and climate change to education, agriculture, and civil rights enforcement. These professionals must be free to follow the facts wherever they lead. Reclassifying them as at-will employees introduces unacceptable risks of political interference, data manipulation, and suppression of inconvenient truths.

Counting people, protecting public health, and assessing our economy are not partisan acts—they are civic imperatives. This rule, by making experts vulnerable to dismissal based on subjective notions of "policy influence," undermines the very integrity of our federal workforce and threatens the quality and credibility of the data that inform democratic governance.

Moreover, this proposed rule runs counter to the bipartisan Foundations for Evidence-Based Policymaking Act of 2018, which recognized the vital need for federal data to be collected and used without bias or undue influence. It is not difficult to foresee how this rule would chill scientific speech, reduce retention of federal talent, and erode public trust in government data and services.
In a time when evidence-based decision-making is more important than ever, the solution is not to weaken protections for scientists and statisticians, but to reinforce their ability to do their work without fear or favor.
I respectfully urge you to withdraw this proposed rule in its entirety.

Sincerely,
Jesse Canchola, MS, PStat
Principal Statistician
StatCon Consulting

title: Comment from Sarah Linden
comment:
I write in strong opposition to the proposed rule titled *"Restoring Accountability to Policy-Influencing Positions Within the Federal Workforce"* (Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004-0001). Far from promoting accountability, this rule would dangerously politicize the career civil service, subverting the merit principles codified in the **Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA)** and undermining constitutional protections that guard against arbitrary and politically motivated employment actions.

This proposed rule directly conflicts with the core mandates of the **CSRA (5 U.S.C. §§ 1101 et seq.)**, which enshrines merit system principles as the bedrock of federal employment. Section 2301(b)(8) of the CSRA specifically provides that “employees should be protected against arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or coercion for partisan political purposes.” The Schedule F framework contemplated by this rule would strip due process protections from potentially thousands of career civil servants—precisely the type of arbitrary, political interference the CSRA was enacted to prevent.

Moreover, the rule attempts to redefine and expand the scope of "policy-influencing positions" without statutory authority. Congress has not delegated OPM or the Executive Branch the discretion to bypass civil service protections wholesale by executive fiat. In fact, courts have consistently held that the **nondelegation doctrine** prohibits agencies from arrogating such sweeping powers absent a clear congressional mandate (*Whitman v. American Trucking Ass'ns*, 531 U.S. 457 (2001)).

The proposed rule also implicates serious **Fifth Amendment due process concerns**. Federal employees in the competitive service have a constitutionally protected property interest in their continued employment. Removing their protections without individualized due process hearings violates established procedural safeguards (*Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill*, 470 U.S. 532 (1985)). A mass reclassification of career employees to an at-will status would invite widespread litigation and erode public confidence in the federal government’s commitment to constitutional norms.

Additionally, by consolidating power over hiring and firing into the hands of politically appointed agency heads, this rule raises serious **separation of powers concerns**. It blurs the line between the apolitical implementation of laws by the Executive Branch and partisan control over the machinery of government. A politicized civil service would inhibit Congress's ability to rely on nonpartisan agencies for oversight and undermine the administrative state's legitimacy—an issue the Supreme Court has warned against in cases such as *Free Enterprise Fund v. PCAOB*, 561 U.S. 477 (2010).

The rule proposed under Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004-0001 is not a restoration of accountability—it is an open invitation to political retaliation, ideological purges, and the dismantling of a merit-based civil service. It contravenes statutory law, violates constitutional protections, and endangers the stability and impartiality of the federal workforce. title: Comment from John Corlett
comment:
I am writing in strong opposition to the proposed rule.
This rule is a dangerous overreach that threatens both the rule of law and the health and safety of the American people. By attempting to reclassify career civil servants into a new “Policy/Career” category, the Executive Branch is ignoring clear statutory limits set by Congress through the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978. Only Congress has the constitutional authority to determine the structure and protections of the civil service. Bypassing that authority not only undermines the separation of powers — a foundational principle of our democracy — but also risks eroding public trust in government institutions.
The proposal also strips away basic due process rights guaranteed under the Fifth Amendment. It would allow for mass dismissals of career employees without the safeguards of notice, explanation, or appeal, opening the door to political retaliation and cronyism. This is fundamentally un-American and invites constitutional challenges the government is unlikely to withstand.
Beyond the legal violations, the human cost of this rule would be enormous. I have spent more than 40 years working in health and human services, and throughout my career, I have worked closely with many talented and dedicated federal public servants. I am deeply grateful for their professionalism, expertise, and steadfast commitment to serving the American people, regardless of political pressures. Their work has been critical to advancing public health, safeguarding vulnerable populations, and ensuring government programs function effectively and fairly.
Politicizing these essential roles — particularly in public health and health care — would not only diminish the quality of government services but could endanger lives. We need experienced, nonpartisan experts leading responses to disease outbreaks, regulating the safety of medicines, and administering critical programs like Medicare and Medicaid. Undermining their independence would slow emergency responses, weaken public protections, and ultimately harm the very people government is meant to serve.
For the sake of the Constitution, the integrity of the civil service, and the health and safety of the American people, this proposal must be withdrawn.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am writing to express my strong opposition to any proposal that would expand the use of Schedule F or reclassify federal employees into a new employment category that undermines merit-based civil service protections.

Schedule F threatens the core principles of a nonpartisan, professional federal workforce. The merit system exists to ensure that government employees are hired and retained based on their skills, experience, and ability to serve the American people — not based on political loyalty. Expanding Schedule F would allow for the politicization of thousands of federal jobs, leading to instability, favoritism, and the erosion of public trust in our government institutions.

Federal employees must be able to carry out their duties without fear of political retribution. The existing civil service system protects the integrity and continuity of government operations across administrations, ensuring that expertise and institutional knowledge are preserved for the benefit of all Americans, regardless of which political party holds office.

Turning career civil servants into political appointees would damage agency effectiveness, discourage talented individuals from public service, and ultimately harm the public by reducing the quality, consistency, and fairness of government services.

I urge you to reject any efforts to revive, expand, or implement policies similar to Schedule F. Our democracy depends on a fair, professional, and nonpartisan federal workforce.

Thank you for considering this comment

title: Comment from Jose Espitia
comment:
I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed rule aimed at "strengthening employee accountability" by creating Schedule Policy/Career within the excepted service and removing due process protections for employees in policy-influencing positions. While the stated goals of accountability and democratic responsiveness are important, this rule, in its current form, poses significant risks to the integrity of the civil service and the principles of fairness and due process.

The removal of Chapter 43 and 75 protections, including Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) appeals, for a broad category of "policy-influencing" career employees is deeply concerning. This action would essentially create a system of at-will employment for a significant portion of the federal workforce, making them vulnerable to arbitrary or politically motivated removal without adequate recourse. The historical context provided in the proposed rule itself highlights the dangers of a purely patronage-based system, which this rule risks resurrecting in a new guise.

While the proposal claims to maintain nonpartisan hiring for Schedule Policy/Career positions, the lack of meaningful job security and appeal rights inherently politicizes these roles. Employees in these positions would be incentivized to align themselves with the political preferences of the current administration, rather than providing objective and expert advice based on their professional expertise and the best interests of the public. This could lead to a decline in the quality and impartiality of policy recommendations and the erosion of the institutional knowledge that career civil servants provide.

Furthermore, the definition of "policy-influencing" positions appears overly broad and lacks clear, objective criteria. This ambiguity creates the potential for the rule to be applied to a wide range of employees, extending far beyond high-level decision-makers and encompassing individuals whose roles involve technical expertise or the implementation of established policies. Subjecting these dedicated public servants to at-will employment based on such a vague definition is unjust and undermines the principles of a merit-based civil service, where career professionals are selected and retained based on their qualifications and performance, not their political leanings.

The argument that current Chapter 43 and 75 procedures are overly burdensome and impede accountability should be addressed through targeted reforms to those processes, rather than a wholesale removal of fundamental employee protections. Streamlining procedures and ensuring timely resolution of performance issues are legitimate goals, but they should not come at the cost of due process and the creation of a politicized workforce.

In conclusion, I urge OPM to reconsider this proposed rule. Instead of dismantling essential employee protections and risking the politicization of the civil service, efforts should focus on refining existing performance management systems to ensure both accountability and fairness. The creation of Schedule Policy/Career, without adequate safeguards, represents a dangerous step backward that would undermine the professionalism, independence, and effectiveness of the federal workforce.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Office of Personnel Management 
Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004 

I strongly oppose the implementation of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposed rule poses a direct threat to the merit-based civil service system that has upheld of a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

According to the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), this rule could allow approximately 50,000 federal employees—or roughly 2% of the career civil service, particularly those involved in policy-making and analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause. Schedule F would open the door to politically motivated hiring and firing practices, eroding the integrity and independence of the civil service. 

Federal career professionals entered public service with a commitment to serve the American people – a duty that they carry as their personal and professional mission. Their roles are essential to the functioning of our government and the protection of public health, safety, and welfare. Those potentially affected by Schedule F include employees who administer critical grants to state and local health departments, assess the effectiveness of public health programs, and design interventions to address pressing issues such as chronic disease—all mission-critical functions at agencies like the CDC.

The American people deserve a federal workforce that is professional, competent, and politically neutral. The implementation of Schedule F would compromise that standard and jeopardize the very foundation of good governance.
