title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
With regard to the proposed OPM rule to politicize the civil service via the Schedule Policy/Career reclassification of federal employees, removing their civil service protections, and rendering them at-will workers, subject to illegal terminations based on baseless political preference. As a concerned American and decorated combat Veteran, I argue that the proposed rule is unlawful, procedurally deficient, and contrary to the public interest, particularly for the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). The rule should be withdrawn with prejudice immediately based on the following legal rational:
First, it is a violation of Statutory Civil Service Protections. The proposed rule undermines the merit-based civil service system codified in Title 5 of the U.S. Code, particularly 5 U.S.C. § 2301, which mandates that federal employment be based on merit principles, free from political influence. By reclassifying employees in “policy-influencing” roles as at-will workers, the rule effectively nullifies protections against arbitrary dismissal, violating 5 U.S.C. § 7511, which guarantees adverse action procedures for competitive and excepted service employees. For VHA employees, the rule also conflicts with Title 38 protections (38 U.S.C. § 7401 et seq.), which prioritize stable staffing to ensure quality veteran healthcare. The Department of Veterans Affairs’ planned reduction of 83,000 jobs, tied to this rule, risks destabilizing VHA operations, contravening Congress’s intent to prioritize veterans’ care. 

Second, this rule is a violation of the Arbitrary and Capricious clause under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A), agency actions must not be arbitrary or capricious. The proposed rule fails to provide a reasoned basis for reclassifying employees, relying on vague criteria for “policy-influencing” positions that lack clear standards, and are subject to the whims of political sycophants. OPM’s estimate of impacting ~50,000 employees, including VHA administrative staff, is unsupported by data demonstrating how these roles undermine agency efficiency or necessitate at-will status. The rule also ignores the chilling effect on employee morale and recruitment, particularly in VHA, where staffing shortages already impair care delivery. OPM’s failure to analyze alternatives, such as targeted performance management reforms, renders the rule arbitrary and capricious.
Third, your insufficient comment period violates is a procedural deficiency in the Rule making process. The APA requires meaningful public participation (5 U.S.C. § 553). The 30-day comment period, ending May 23, 2025, is insufficient for a rule with such far-reaching consequences, especially given OPM’s bypassing of standard regulatory steps (e.g., declaring Biden-era protections inoperative). This curtailed process limits stakeholders, including Veterans, from fully assessing the rule’s impact. Additionally, OPM has not disclosed sufficient data on affected positions or economic impacts, violating APA transparency requirements.
The rule jeopardizes the public interest by politicizing the federal workforce, undermining 5 U.S.C. § 1103’s mandate for OPM to uphold merit principles. For VHA, the rule’s alignment with the VA’s August 2025 RIF threatens healthcare access for veterans, as administrative roles are critical to clinical operations. This conflicts with Congressional directives in the Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 to prioritize veteran services. The rule’s reliance on Project 2025’s privatization goals further suggests an intent to weaken public institutions, contrary to Congress’s commitment to a robust VA.
Additionally, the rule raises due process concerns under the Fifth Amendment by depriving employees of protected property interests in their jobs without adequate notice or hearing. Reclassification to at-will status, followed by potential termination without appeal rights, denies procedural protections established in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill (1985). This is particularly egregious for VHA employees with veteran status, who are entitled to hiring and retention preferences under 5 U.S.C. § 2108.
To conclude, your rule is blatantly unlawful, procedurally flawed, and detrimental to the federal workforce and veterans’ care. OPM should withdraw the rule or, at minimum, extend the comment period, provide detailed impact analyses, and revise the rule to comply with Title 5, Title 38, and APA requirements. I urge OPM to prioritize merit-based employment and protect VHA’s ability to serve veterans.

This is particularly egregious for VHA employees with veteran status, who are entitled to hiring and retention preferences under 5 U.S.C. § 2108.

OPM should withdraw the rule or, at minimum, extend the comment period, provide detailed impact analyses, and revise the rule to comply with Title 5, Title 38, and APA requirements. I urge OPM to prioritize merit-based employment and protect VHA’s ability to serve veterans.

title: Comment from Abigail Hoiles
comment:
The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883 and the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 were crucial pieces of legislation that decreased political influence within the federal workforce. Prior to these acts, government jobs were often awarded based on political connections or nepotism. These acts marked a significant step in creating a meritocracy rather than a "spoils system." We have been better off because of them; civil servants have been able to remain consistent and unbiased in their work despite the consistent rotation of elected politicians from different parties.

The bias in the language of this rule change summary is telling: "This will allow agencies to quickly remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct, perform poorly, or undermine the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives." In other words, if employees refused to follow Presidential directives--even directives that may be illegal or immoral--agencies could suspend, reassign, reduce in force, or remove employees without having to go through any of the steps required under the Civil Service Act. 

This proposed rule to implement the Schedule F designation for career civil servants is a bad idea. It would remove important checks and balances that allow career civil servants to do their jobs well and without undue influence of political bias. 

There are other methods already in place that allow ineffective federal employees to be removed. This rule change should not be approved.

title: Comment from Thomas Paine
comment:
For more than 150 years, America has relied on a professional civil service that takes an oath to the Constitution to faithfully enact the laws no matter which party is in power.  This rule is trying to take us back to the corrupt “spoils system” by replacing nonpartisan civil servants with handpicked cronies who are loyal only to a would-be monarch, not America. 
I strongly oppose weakening the current professional civil service system. The current rules are sufficient for improving performance, accountability, and responsiveness IF Executive branch leadership is competent, committed to America's interests, and follows the rule of law.

title: Comment from G T
comment:
American biomedical science became preeminent because the NIH system allows expert scientists to set priorities, and working scientists to put forward their best most creative work that is then exhaustively reviewed by other experts for feasibility and impact. Sustained scientific progress cannot be proscribed from the top, because most important discoveries are serendipitous, and important breakthroughs and cures must build upon the knowledge generated through unfettered, often exploratory research. 

This proposed change will degrade the ability of NIH to promote the best science by making it easier for whichever party is in power to control what science gets done. Putting political appointees in positions to set research priorities leaves the system vulnerable to ideologically manipulation, which means money and time will be wasted, and important discoveries will not be made. This was the path taken by Russian science after WWII, and the gulf that opened up between American and Russian biomedical scientific impact is illustrative of how inefficient that approach is. NIH and the science it has funded is an economic powerhouse, and should be seen as an investment rather than an expense. Making this system less efficient and more beholden to political whims is antithetical to the goal of investing in the best science.

title: Comment from Stefan  Frisch
comment:
This policy change is incoherent. 

You claim the positions are non-partisan but explicitly indicate the president's agenda as a reason for dismissal. 

You claim the change is to remove poor performance but again indicate dismissal for disagreement with the president's agenda. 

Democracy is not the same thing as the president's agenda. Since the democracy involves federal election for four offices by each voter, democracy involves considering not just the president, but also the representative and the two senators that each voter has. 

This policy will also be financially wasteful. Each federal employee that changes every time there's a new president brings a degree of inefficiency due to the transition.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the proposed rule (OPM-2025-0004-0001) that seeks to create a new “Schedule Policy/Career” category within the federal civil service. This proposal would NOT improve performance and accountability BUT WOULD dangerously erode the merit-based foundations of the federal workforce and risks politicizing what has historically been a nonpartisan, professional civil service who only answers to the constitution NOT to a person or political party. 

First, by exempting policy-related positions from adverse action protections, the proposal would allow political appointees or new administrations to remove career employees based solely on political loyalty rather than competence or adherence to law and scientific standards. This would replace institutional knowledge, technical expertise, and continuity in governance with ideological conformity. It risks creating a workforce where federal employees are hired or fired based on their political allegiance rather than their qualifications or performance.

Second, this change would all but guarantee mass turnover in federal staffing every four years, or even more frequently, depending on shifts in executive leadership. Agencies could be emptied of experienced personnel each time the Presidency changes hands, severely disrupting essential services and the government’s ability to function consistently and impartially. This instability would harm not only internal agency operations but also the American public who rely on a stable, competent federal workforce.

Third, the proposal reintroduces the worst elements of the “spoils system” that plagued American governance in the 19th century — a system the civil service reforms of the late 1800s (particularly the Pendleton Act) were explicitly designed to eliminate. The return to a patronage-based system would invite widespread abuse by the executive branch, with political loyalty prioritized over merit, expertise, and the public interest. It would undo more than a century of progress in creating a professional civil service dedicated to impartial service to the nation, not service to a particular political leader.

In short, the proposed rule would politicize federal service, destabilize agency operations, and undo critical reforms that have safeguarded the integrity of government for generations. I respectfully urge OPM to withdraw this rule in the interest of preserving a CRITICAL nonpartisan, professional, and effective civil service for the American people not beholden to a party or person!

title: Comment from H Evelyn
comment:
I strongly oppose the reinstatement and amendment of Executive Order 13957 under the guise of "Restoring Accountability" within the federal workforce. This action undermines the foundational principles of a professional, nonpartisan civil service by allowing sweeping reclassifications of career employees into a new "Policy/Career" category, stripping them of critical civil service protections.

By enabling political appointees to remove experienced, apolitical federal employees based on subjective judgments about "faithfully implementing" administration policies, this order injects political loyalty tests into positions that are meant to serve the public interest, not partisan agendas. It opens the door to widespread politicization, chilling independent advice, honest analysis, and ethical decision-making that are vital to good governance.

The civil service was intentionally structured to prevent political interference and ensure that government expertise serves the American people consistently across administrations. Gutting these protections risks turning the federal workforce into an unstable, revolving door of politically favored individuals rather than a steady, expert-driven institution.

I urge the administration to withdraw this executive order and instead strengthen the merit-based system that has long protected the impartiality of our federal workforce.

title: Comment from Sandra Hewett
comment:
I write in opposition. The Pendleton Act of 1883 created the merit-based civil service specifically to end the “spoils system,” where government jobs were handed out as political rewards.
	•	Studies, like from the Partnership for Public Service, show that nonpartisan, experienced civil servants improve government efficiency and trust.
	•	Legal experts (e.g., from the Brennan Center for Justice) warn Schedule F would politicize agencies and weaken public trust.

Schedule F would let politicians fire career government workers just because they don’t like what they say or how they do their jobs. That’s dangerous. We rely on experienced, nonpartisan experts to keep things running — like making sure Social Security checks go out or public health advice is based on science, not politics. When politicians can replace experts with loyalists, it leads to corruption, worse services, and decisions based on politics instead of facts. After all, the civil service system was set up over 100 years ago to stop this kind of political abuse.

comment:
Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004]
RIN 3206-AO80

I have seen government employees removed for poor performance. The process requires informing the employee of the performance issue, documenting the performance issue, and setting a plan with the employee to improve their performance. If performance does not improve, the employee is removed. It is neither too lengthy nor too cumbersome. It is reasonable to ensure that the performance issue is an issue with the employee and not with the training, procedures, or culture of an office. 

The proposed rule would not address employee performance, it would ensure the removal of employees who uphold any rule of law that an administration does not want to be bound by. The proposed rule is one nail in the coffin of democracy.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the proposed Schedule F rule, which would reclassify federal employees in policy-related roles as ‘excepted service’ positions, stripping them of competitive service protections. This move undermines the merit-based civil service system, violates the intent of the Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA) of 1978, and risks enabling political patronage

Erosion of Merit System Principles - Cite 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b) - which mandates that federal personnel actions be based on merit and free from political coercion.
- Schedule F violates this by allowing removals without cause, incentivizing loyalty over competence.

CSRA’s prohibition (5 U.S.C. § 1103(a)) against creating new excepted service categories without Congress’s authority. OPM’s rule exceeds its statutory limits.
- Note that the Supreme Court’s United States v. Perkins 1886) and Elrod v. Burns (1976) rulings bar patronage-based firings for non-policymaking roles. Schedule F’s broad definition of "policy-related" positions risks unconstitutional politicization

Schedule F could enable *mass firings of nonpartisan experts (e.g., scientists, economists) to replace them with political loyalists, as warned by the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) v. Trump litigation (2020).
- Point to historical precedent The Pendleton Act (1883) and CSRA were enacted to end the spoils system; Schedule F revives it.

Career stability is essential for effective governance. Example: During the 2020 transition, Schedule F threatened to disrupt pandemic response by destabilizing agency leadership.

5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(12) Prohibits undermining merit system principles.

5 CFR Part 302 Limits excepted service hiring; Schedule F circumvents these safeguards.
Precedent: Chevron U.S.A. v. NRDC* (1984) – OPM’s interpretation may overreach statutory authority.

OPM must withdraw Schedule F. If finalized, the rule should be challenged in court for violating the CSRA and the Constitution’s separation of powers by granting the Executive Branch unchecked authority over employment decisions.

title: Comment from Juliana Perry
comment:
This rule reclasses federal policy roles—making it easy to fire civil servants without cause. The description alleges that these positions will continue to be nonpartisan, but at-will employment makes it far too easy to inject partisan politics and loyalty tests into the process. 
My family members who are civil servants have loyally served across multiple administrations, bringing their decades of experience and perspective to the work-- this is the stability we need in government, not the random destruction of the civil service at a whim every 4-8 years. 

This is merely Schedule F 2.0—revived from Trump’s 2020 executive order, only broader. 

We need career officials who follow facts, not party lines. Any other approach creates wasted effort and talent. This affects everything from public health to disaster response to justice.

There are existing mechanisms in place for performance plans and firing employees who are truly not able to perform in their roles. 

This isn’t about fixing bureaucratic inefficiency. We need an independent civil service that can steadily work across multiple administrations, stewarding the resources of all for the benefit of all.

title: Comment from Timothy McDermott
comment:
Office of Personnel Management
5 CFR Parts 210, 212, 213, 302, 432, 451, and 752
[Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004]
RIN 3206-AO80

I am submitting my comments in response to the following policy announcement document (information above). As an early-career funded scientist at NIH, I have a fundamental concern with the policy announcement as it relates to appointing/removing NIH leadership in a nonpartisan way. There is a direct contradiction in the summary when it is stated that "these positions will remain career jobs filled on a nonpartisan basis" with a follow-up that the policy will provide a justification to "quickly remove employees from critical positions who ... undermine the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives". Involving Presidential directives in the decision making process about whether to hire/remove staff is inherently partisan and undermines the objective nature of the scientific process. Scientific misconduct and poor performance might be justifiable reasons to remove staff, but the Presidential directive text is highly concerning to me as a junior scientist. Regardless of the party in power, it does not seem appropriate to subject scientific officials at NIH to this partisan pressure.

title: Comment from Lori Setton
comment:
In the history of our government, those appointed to policy-influencing positions are typically very senior hires with a long track record that is publicly available.  That is the point of these hires - they come in with experience, a history of success with program building and overcoming challenges.  There is no reason for these positions to be at-will positions because this is not a new hire, they do not need a probationary period.  There exist procedures and processes by which agencies can remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct or perform poorly in the eyes of a community of engaged stakeholders.  The interpretation of not supporting or undermining the democratic process is entirely subjective, and can not be used as a basis for removing employees from policy-influencing positions.

Similarly, to allow removal of an employee in a policy-influencing position based on "intentionally" subverting Presidential directives is subjective, and a wholly erroneous application of Presidential directives in the governance of our affairs.

I am deeply opposed to the implementation of this proposed change to Schedule F as written.

Lori Setton
MO-02

comment:

The U.S. government has operated for over two hundred years with people of different beliefs and values working in various agencies. A government that requires people to be “yes men/women” is not a free democratic government, it is a dictatorship. This potential new policy change on employee classification should NOT be made.

comment:
Dear Office of Personnel Management,
I am writing to express serious concerns regarding the proposed rule to create Schedule Policy/Career positions within the excepted service. While I understand the stated goal of enhancing accountability, this rule is fundamentally flawed legally and as a matter of policy. Below, I outline specific issues related to statutory conflicts, constitutional challenges, procedural deficiencies, and broader policy implications.
 
1. Conflict with Statutory Protections
The proposed rule appears to contravene several provisions of the Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA), which established a uniform framework for employee protections. Specifically:
•Adverse Action Rights: By excluding Schedule Policy/Career employees from Chapters 43 and 75 of Title 5, the rule strips them of procedural safeguards, including the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) appeal rights. This exclusion undermines Congress’s intent to provide federal employees with due process and fair treatment, as affirmed in cases like United States v. Fausto (484 U.S. 439 [1988]).
•Merit System Principles: The merit system principles enshrined in Title 5, Section 2301(b), emphasize nonpartisan retention based on performance. Converting these roles into at-will positions risks politicization, directly contravening these principles.
 
2. Constitutional Concerns
•Fifth Amendment – Due Process: The removal of appeal rights infringes upon employees’ constitutional property interests in their jobs, as recognized in Arnett v. Kennedy (416 U.S. 134 [1974]). This lack of due process poses significant constitutional challenges.
•First Amendment – Free Speech: Creating at-will positions could have a chilling effect on employees’ ability to express dissenting or critical views, even outside their professional duties. Such policies risk violating precedents like Pickering v. Board of Education (391 U.S. 563 [1968]), which protect employees’ rights to free expression.
 
3. Violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA)
•Lack of Rational Basis: The rule's justification relies on anecdotal evidence rather than a robust analysis of systemic challenges. The cited difficulties in addressing poor performance and misconduct are not substantiated with comprehensive data, falling short of the APA’s requirement for reasoned decision-making (Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association v. State Farm, 463 U.S. 29 [1983]).
•Arbitrary and Capricious Action: The rule’s sweeping changes ignore less intrusive alternatives for addressing performance issues. This lack of proportionality may render the rule arbitrary under the APA.
•Insufficient Public Engagement: If comments are inadequately addressed or the decision appears predetermined, it could lead to procedural violations, further invalidating the rule.
 
4. Policy Implications
•Undermining Nonpartisanship: Federal employment is merit-based, a cornerstone of public trust in government. This rule risks politicizing critical roles by allowing terminations based on subjective evaluations, which could erode that trust.
•	Impact on Workforce Morale and Recruitment: Moving key positions to at-will status may create a culture of fear and instability, deterring highly qualified professionals from seeking public service roles. This could significantly weaken the federal government’s institutional expertise over time.
•Unintended Consequences: The rule may foster a toxic work environment by discouraging whistleblowing and incentivizing compliance over ethical or professional judgment, potentially diminishing overall efficiency and accountability.

The proposed rule poses substantial legal and policy challenges. It undermines statutory protections, raises constitutional concerns, and conflicts with the core principles of the civil service. Furthermore, it negatively affects workforce morale, public trust, and government efficiency.

I urge the Office of Personnel Management to withdraw this proposed rule and instead explore alternative measures that address performance challenges without compromising legal protections or the integrity of the federal workforce.

title: Comment from Christopher Adams
comment:
**To:** Office of Personnel Management  
**Re:** Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service  
**Docket ID:** OPM-2025-0004  

I respectfully urge the Office of Personnel Management to withdraw the proposed reclassification rule.  By carving approximately 50,000 positions out from longstanding civil service protections, this change opens the door to politicized firings rather than performance-based actions.  America’s merit system was established to ensure career federal employees can carry out the public’s business free from partisan pressure; stripping these employees of due-process safeguards undermines that core principle.

Career civil servants play a critical role in maintaining continuity, expertise, and trust across administrations.  When non-supervisory staff fear dismissal for expressing views or implementing policies they believe in, morale and retention will suffer—and the federal government will lose talented professionals to the private sector.  This rule, if finalized, will chill open discourse, encourage loyalty pledges over competence, and discourage qualified individuals from public service.

Rather than eroding the neutrality of the federal workforce, OPM should focus on enhancing existing performance-management tools—such as clear, consistent evaluation criteria and robust training for supervisors—while preserving essential appeal rights.  Punitive reclassification is a blunt instrument that fails to address genuine performance issues and instead invites politically motivated dismissals.

For these reasons, I oppose the proposed rule and request that OPM uphold the merit-based civil service system.  Thank you for your consideration.

Respectfully,  
Christopher Adams

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
As a civil servant this proposed rule is alarming and detrimental to the operation of our country. With political appointees, there is no need to create this schedule of personnel unless the goal is to create a more partisan civil service. Further, by moving career positions into this new schedule, critical roles that subject matter experts fill (at a far reduced rate than they could get in the private sector) would cease being attractive to leading experts. This will create an overall drain that will put the US behind for decades. Additionally, this rule can create high turnover in positions and subject areas that have historically seen stability. This will lead to repeated loss of agency institutional knowledge which is critical to maintain from one administration to the next to keep the country running smoothly.

How does this rule protect institutional knowledge at the agencies?
What protections are in place to prevent high turnover in positions that will be rescheduled and no longer have full civil service protections from political action taken against them?

The guidelines for what positions to reschedule in this rule are vague and can be interpreted by each agency to include few or most of their current civil servant positions. How is this efficient or serving the American people?

If we are to keep the civil service non-partisan, is this walking back of the April 2024 rule created under the prior administration not a clear example of enacting an agenda based on a partisan agenda? 

If the next administration issues an executive order rescinding this order and eliminating this new Schedule Career/Policy, then are we not now engaged in an ongoing political tug-of-war with the civil service?

title: Comment from Mark Wilson
comment:
Thanks for the opportunity to comment.

I oppose any change that would allow someone to be fired because it was determined that they “undermine[d] the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives.”

Civil servants serve the American people, not the presidency, no matter who that president is. Their ability to serve us—the people—across many administrations greatly improves their ability to develop in their careers and retain institutional knowledge that benefits the American people. If every civil servant faces dismissal just because they don’t follow the party line of who is in office, then we will never be able to retain good civil servants, and our country will suffer greatly.

The current administration has shown that it is willing to flout laws and the Constitution, and to fire federal employees at the whim of an unelected foreign-born person. It should never be given the opportunity to fire people because they do not follow his political bent. 

I oppose any effort to enable a civil servant to be dismissed because they “undermine[d] the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives.” It is short-sighted, foolish, and unAmerican.

title: Comment from Joan Rogers
comment:
This legislation is not going to improve federal service or help the American people. By politicizing these jobs, you create an environment where the laws and regulations that appeal to each party can be emphasized and funded, while the ones that do not align with the administration in charge are defunded and disbanded. The American people are then eft with an abundance of confusion about what they can count on from each Agency. The American people deserve better than that! They deserve a consistent, well-serving Federal workforce made up of people from all walks of life and all political, economic, and racial groups. When the Federal workforce is aligned like the populace they serve, the service is fairer, and more consistent. And by not switching priorities every 2-4 years, the populace will know what to expect and how the Federal workforce will serve them at the present and into the future. This creates a secure America!
For example: if a person wanted to open a business that would distribute food products across the country. They would be subject to Federal FDA rules. If the current administration didn't want, or didn't fund a robust inspection program to enforce the rules, the business owner might open their business without the food protections that cost them considerable money. The food could be harmful and the American people could be at risk of getting sick. But even if that doesn't come to pass, if a differently aligned political party comes into power 2-4 years later, and a robust inspection program is funded, the new business owner could get inspected and found to be deficient. NOW they have to put in equipment or process that cost money, perhaps money they don't have. They were caught in an uncertain business climate and now they may have to take out loans to cover the cost or dip into the business's cash, or raise prices, or go out of business. This scenario can be thought through in the opposite direction, as well. Either way, it isn't fair to the business owner, the consumers, or the investors. 
Another scenario: A young person who loves working in the outdoors considers a job at the National Park Service after high school. Due to a learning disability, they do not do well in a school setting and are sure that college is not for them. But they have a service-minded personality and would be thrilled to work in a National Park, cleaning up after disrespectful tourists, manning a booth taking admission fees, maintaining trails and assisting with conservation efforts. When this person graduates from high school, the political climate is favorable to become a NPS employee and they take a job with the NPS. After a number of years doing exceptional work, this person marries, buys a house, has children and enjoys the security of the job. But after a number of years, a new political administration comes in that doesn't believe that our National Parks are a treasure to protect and decides that the NPS workforce can be severely reduced and this person is fired (RIF'd). They have no college education and are now unemployed with a mortgage and family to support. Perhaps they could go to a state park to work and make considerably less pay, but they will probably have to take a job that doesn't align with their personality, skills, and experience. This is unfair to the worker. And it is unfair to the American people who want to enjoy our National Parks and need them to be maintained to do so! Having this priority at risk of changing on a whim, is not fair to the American people. Some may have chosen to live near, or spend their money to travel to these parks. They expect a consistent experience and deserve it if they are going to spend their hard-earned money on frequenting them.
People say that this can happen at any job - any company can lay off any worker. But a company is different than a Federal Service. A company is a for-profit entity that needs to do what it has to - to stay in business. Federal Agencies are not for-profit companies. The American government is NOT a for-profit company. And it shouldn't be treated as such. Yes, the government should run as efficiently as possible, but service consistency MUST be maintained. Hiring and firing people at the will of each political party will destroy consistency. 
Yes, the Federal deficit is huge! But trying to balance that by firing federal workers is not an efficient way to do that. The Federal Agencies ALL provide value and increase revenues over the long term. Inefficiencies and unproductive workers should be weeded out, and has been over each political party. But by making Federal workers at-will employees would hurt America over the long-term. 
I do not support changing Federal workers into at-will employees. I think it is a poorly thought out idea that will destroy our American services and hurt ALL Americans.

title: Comment from Colleen Hearn
comment: This proposal strips veteran employees of their vet preference. Vet preference is an earned employment category that most public state and federal agencies recognize and utilize to encourage veterans to continue their service to Americans. By converting career employees with vet preference to schedule F, you remove the RIF categories which includes vet preference and protects veterans from being terminated before non veterans. 30% of the federal workforce are people who have served their country honorably. This administration should consider EXCLUDING veterans from this category and allow them to retain their job protections as a veteran. Unemployment and homelessness among veterans is an ongoing concern and complex issue. The government should be taking care of veterans not removing the employment protections they earned through serving this country.

title: Comment from J H
comment:
Good Day,
I am commenting on the following:

1.  Amending 5 CFR part 213 (Excepted Service) to include Schedule Policy/Career as an excepted service schedule for policy-influencing career positions, while clarifying that Schedule C appointments are exclusively for noncareer (politicall appointments with policy responsibilities.

Statement:
Allowing career employees to be moved into a new "excepted service" category for policy jobs, while calling it an effort to "increase accountability to the President," fundamentally shifts career service away from its nonpartisan mission.

Why it should not be implemented::
This change politicizes career positions that are supposed to serve the American people, not any one President. It erodes trust in the civil service, discourages qualified applicants, and risks the public receiving biased, politically driven service instead of neutral, expert support.

2. Amending 5 CFR part 212 (Competitive Service and Competitive Status):
Statement:
Letting employees keep their competitive status "on paper" while actually stripping them of competitive service protections undermines both employee rights and the principle of fair, merit-based government.

Why it should not be implemented:
This creates a false sense of security for employees while weakening the systems that protect them from unfair treatment. For the public, it means less stability and independence in the federal workforce, making it harder for agencies to consistently deliver services without political interference.

3. Amending 5 CFR part 752 (Adverse Actions) and part 432 (Performance-Based Actions):
Statement:
Removing due process rights — like appeal protections and performance review procedures — for employees shifted into Schedule Policy/Career roles opens the door to arbitrary firings based on politics, not merit.

Why it should not be implemented:
Without fair procedures, employees can be removed for political reasons, not job performance. This weakens the entire public service system, leading to instability, fear, and loss of experienced staff, which ultimately hurts the public who depend on expert, stable government services.

4. Amending 5 CFR part 210 (Definitions Related to Political Appointments):
Statement:
Changing the definition so that career employees can now hold "policy-influencing" roles — once reserved for political appointees — invites political favoritism into what should be a professional, merit-based civil service.

Why it should not be implemented:
This undermines the tradition that career employees serve the country, not a political agenda. It risks critical decisions being shaped by political loyalty rather than expertise, harming the quality and impartiality of services that the public deserves.

5. Amending 5 CFR part 302 (Procedures for Moving Employees into Policy Positions):
Statement:
Removing rules that provided oversight and appeal rights when moving employees into policy roles guts transparency and makes it easier to sideline or oust employees without fair warning or review.

Why it should not be implemented:
When movements and staffing changes happen in the shadows, without accountability, corruption and favoritism grow. The public will suffer as federal agencies lose skilled, nonpartisan staff and become more focused on political loyalty than on serving the people fairly and effectively.

title: Comment from Alexandra Dailey
comment:
Keep politics out of government administration of services to the people.  We need people experienced in their field, who know how to work within the system that was set up to protect administration from changes in political leadership.  Civil service is about service delivery, not political views.  Policies can change - they need to be made law by Congress, our elected representatives.  

Our system is the envy of the world - that's what being great is all about.  

Government can be made more efficient, and there is money to be saved.  But slashing without regard to costs of the effect is not the way to save $.  It is only to create chaos and destroy our system of service delivery to the people.

title: Comment from Bruce Toman
comment: I oppose this change to the April 2024 implementation of the rules to implement 5 U.S.C. Chapter 75.  Our democracy needs a professional civil service dedicated to implementing the law.  We need clear and rules to attract and protect people who choose to work in government, for the public good.  This replacement to the regulations issued in April would remove those protections and allow the President to fire a huge swath of the civil service and replace those people with political appointees.   This would not only politicize a workforce that should be nonpartisan - it would open the civil service to corruption. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Office of Personnel Management Proposed Rule "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" - Docket OPM-2025-0004

I am commenting to express my strong and continued opposition to the proposed rule "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" as published in the Federal Register (90 FR 17182), Docket OPM-2025-0004.

The creation of a "Schedule Policy/Career" designation for policy-influencing positions, making them at-will and removing standard adverse action procedures and appeal processes, would fundamentally undermine the principles of a nonpartisan and merit-based civil service. This proposed change appears to inject political considerations into personnel decisions, creating an environment where career employees in critical roles could be removed for reasons other than poor performance or misconduct, specifically for perceived disloyalty to an administration's policy directives. This politicization would erode the professional independence of the civil service and lead to instability and a loss of valuable expertise within government agencies.

The lack of clear and objective criteria for defining "policy-influencing" positions raises concerns that this could be applied too broadly, impacting a significant number of dedicated civil servants who are not in the most senior policymaking roles. The loss of due process protections for these employees would be a significant step backward in ensuring fair treatment and job security within the federal workforce.

Specific aspects of the proposed rule undermine the ability of policy advisors and agency leaders to fulfill their essential duties:

Undermining the Obligation to Highlight Legal Conflicts: This rule could undermine policy advisors' fundamental obligation to thoroughly analyze and highlight potential conflicts between proposed presidential directives and existing laws, regulations, and legal precedents. The fear of being seen as "intentionally undermining" a directive could discourage advisors from providing critical, objective legal assessments, potentially leading to ill-conceived or legally challenged policies.

Jeopardizing Careers for Respecting Legal Authority: The proposed rule jeopardizes the careers of dedicated policy makers who, in upholding their oath and the rule of law, respect congressional veto overrides or comply with court orders that directly oppose presidential directives. An employee should not face the threat of termination for adhering to the legal framework of our government. This rule creates a dangerous precedent where loyalty to a directive could be prioritized over the obligation to respect the balance of powers.

Compromising Congressional oversight and the Independence of Agency Heads: This proposal compromises the intended role and independence of agency heads who are often approved by Congress and mandated to maintain a degree of autonomy to effectively carry out their agencies' missions. The fear of being deemed to be undermining a presidential directive could pressure these leaders to prioritize political alignment over their statutory obligations and professional judgment, ultimately hindering the effective functioning of government.

Moreover, I want to emphasize that processes already exist within our system of governance to prevent federal employees from subverting the intention of laws and regulations. Mechanisms like the Congressional Review Act (CRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) provide checks to ensure agency actions align with legislative intent and established procedures. The proposed rule appears to disregard these existing robust frameworks designed to ensure accountability and prevent overreach.

Finally, the definition of “policy making or policy influencing” positions in the proposed rule is excessively broad and dangerously open to abuse. Without clear and specific criteria, this designation could be applied arbitrarily to a wide range of career civil servants, including those whose roles have limited direct influence on high-level policy decisions. This lack of precision creates the potential for politically motivated reclassifications and subsequent removals, undermining the merit-based principles of the civil service.

This proposed rule, if implemented, would not only politicize the civil service but also create a chilling effect on objective policy analysis, undermine the rule of law within the executive branch, and compromise the necessary independence of agency leadership. It also disregards existing accountability mechanisms and relies on an overly broad and abusable definition.

I urge the Office of Personnel Management to carefully consider these critical points and abandon this ill-conceived proposal. A robust and effective government relies on a civil service that is both accountable and empowered to provide objective advice and uphold the legal framework of our nation without fear of political reprisal.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I oppose the rulemaking, Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service, and urge OPM and the executive branch not to promulgate this rule in its current form. 
First, is this rule in compliance with APA requirements and 12866 interagency review? With such an expedited turnaround from E.O. to proposal, and no substantive discussion on the economic impacts of this rule, which would seem to be significant in terms of potential mass-firings over time, it appears not.
Secondly, it’s laughable hypocritical that an administration unabashedly dedicated to tit-for-tat patronage in political and staff level appointments (e.g., the DOGE employees selected by Elon Musk, and unelected special employee, now embedded across departments) would pretend to be so concerned with such activities occurring at the lowest levels of government. And the evidence that there are parties attempting to “resist” from within is weak at best, and frankly displays zero understanding of the actual workings of federal agencies, and their dedicated career staff. 
Third, the reliance on a walk through history beginning in the 1800s (when black people were enslaved, women had no rights, and workers would routinely die on the job needlessly due to lack of basic safety requirements) is sad. If you think the 1800s, early 1900s, etc. are the benchmark society that we American citizens want to live in now, please disabuse yourselves of that notion. The forward movement in the laws of the 1960s and 1970s, a time when equality and fairness was finally being paid attention to on a national political level are why those laws should stand, and the protections under those laws via the regulations for civil service protections are good.
Finally, I do believe that it is difficult to ultimately fire certain employees in the civil service, but I do not believe the issue is with the protections they are offered. Rather, I believe that there is a lack of accountability from the top down to address poor performers according to the rules and processes available. A reform at the agency level to ensure existing responsible managers are following the rules that exist would be a more effective and circumspect approach to poor performers.
It is also not clear at what level the ability to fire newly at-will employees would reside. Only managers with direct knowledge of an employees duties and performance should have that ability. This rule does not make that clear.
Go back to the drawing board and study current law, GAO reports, and IG reports to understand how to address the issue of accountability you claim is the goal of this rule. Of course, I don’t think that is the goal, given the backdrop it is proposed against, of mass-firings across government with unfounded or ill-founded reasoning.

title: Comment from Robert Charles
comment:
I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed rule titled "Reforming the Federal Hiring Process and Restoring Merit to Government Service" (OPM-2025-0004-0001). While I support efforts to enhance efficiency and uphold constitutional values within the federal workforce, I am deeply concerned that the proposed changes could undermine the foundational principles of a nonpartisan civil service.

The emphasis on hiring individuals who are "committed to upholding the rule of law and the United States Constitution" and preventing the hiring of those "unwilling to defend the Constitution or to faithfully serve the Executive Branch" raises significant concerns. Such language is vague and could be interpreted to favor individuals who align ideologically with the current administration, thereby facilitating the removal or exclusion of civil service employees based on political beliefs.

This approach appears to contravene the Merit System Principles outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301, which emphasize that federal personnel management should be implemented without regard to political affiliation and should protect employees from arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or coercion for partisan political purposes. Additionally, 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(1) prohibits discrimination for or against any employee or applicant for employment on the basis of political affiliation.

Furthermore, the proposed rule's potential to reclassify positions and alter hiring practices without clear safeguards could erode the protections afforded to career civil servants, leading to a workforce that is more susceptible to political influence and less focused on impartial service to the public.

I urge the Office of Personnel Management to reconsider the proposed rule and ensure that any reforms to the federal hiring process uphold the principles of merit-based employment and protect the nonpartisan nature of the civil service.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: This change to Federal civil service would replace a transparent system that has merit-based hiring and clear review process for employee performance with a simple system where any underperforming employee is given a sing opportunity to improve or be fired.  The new system proposed creates an opaque system to determine 'policy influencing positions' and provide unilateral ability to fire those employees not based on performance, but perceived loyalty to elected officials.  This replaces objective career professionals who are loyal to the U.S. Constitution, rather than elected officials that rotate in and out of power.  This would be detrimental the professionalism and objectivity of career expert civil servants to who defend the Constitution and implement laws passed by Congress with the funding allocated by Congress for the benefit of U.S. taxpayers.  This change is a thinly-veiled attempt to remove objective, professional experts, from being career civil servants and replace them with ideologues loyal to elected officials. The current merit system provides high-quality services.  The existing standards, review requirements, and transparent process for removing poor performers is functioning as intended to ensure that objective, expert, career civil servants are consistently providing quality services.  Creating this new schedule that allows politicians to remove staff they perceive has having different opinions is not in the best interest of the United States.  We should not take the risk of injustice from passion and prejudice, which no law or regulation can control, when there is already a transparent and effective system to remove civil servants that are not effective.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the "Schedule F" classification (irrespective of its current name) for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence. While 5 U.S.C. § 3301 grants the President authority to prescribe regulations for the competitive service, it DOES NOT permit blanket reclassification permission, nor removal of due process rights. 

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in the proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing the proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations. Additionally, the proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule's broad reclassification of policy-related roles likely exceeds OPM's regulatory authority under 5 U.S.C. § 3302, which requires that exceptions to competitive service rules be "necessary" and "conditions of good administration." Courts will likely strike it down as arbitrary and capricious under Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass'n v. State Farm (1983).

In conclusion, the proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. It disregards Title 5 protections, congressional intent, and judicial precedent safeguarding merit-based civil service. If implemented, it invites litigation under the CSRA, APA, and Constitutional doctrines, with a high likelihood of being struck down. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

This order states Schedule Policy/Career employees:

"are required to faithfully implement administration policies to the best of their ability, consistent with their constitutional oath and the vesting of executive authority solely in the President. Failure to do so is grounds for dismissal."

It also states that:

"the President will make the final decision about which positions go into Schedule Policy/Career."

And "guidance about positions agencies should consider in their Schedule Policy/Career positions" includes those with:

"Substantive participation and discretionary authority in agency grantmaking, such as the substantive exercise of discretion in the drafting of funding opportunity announcements, evaluation of grant applications, or recommending or selecting grant recipients. Grantmaking is an important form of policymaking, so employees with a substantive discretionary role in how federal funding gets allocated may occupy policymaking positions."

This indicates that all involved in all grantmaking are considered policymaking positions and that the President can dictate whether those individuals' actions are aligned with their policies -- no matter who the President is or their party affiliation. Those involved in grantmaking should be nonpartisan career civil servants with appropriate expertise and experience to write funding announcements, evaluate grant applications, and recommend grant funding to achieve the missions of their agencies. They should not have to live in fear that their positions would be at risk if their expert-driven, rigorous decision-making is not consistent with one person's opinions. Adoption of this Proposed Rule will have dire consequences on our country's ability to conduct the best research, educate the best trainees, build the best infrastructure, and provide the best services.

title: Comment from Janice Underwood
comment:
Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) titled “Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” (RIN: 3206-AO80):

I strongly oppose the Office of Personnel Management’s proposed rule titled “Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” (RIN: 3206-AO80). While the stated intent may be to improve accountability, this rule would dangerously erode merit system protections and open the door to political retribution, favoritism, and widespread abuse of authority.

This rule poses a serious threat to the merit-based, nonpartisan foundation of the federal workforce. By removing due process protections, the rule invites politicization, undermines the integrity of public service, and risks replacing career expertise with partisan loyalty. The federal government depends on the stability, experience, and impartiality of its career civil servants to deliver services, uphold the law, and advise on complex matters that affect every American.

Creating an at-will class of employees—particularly those whose work may be perceived as “policy-influencing”—would have a chilling effect on employees who are expected to provide objective and lawful guidance, even when it may challenge political priorities.

This proposal is a solution in search of a problem. Existing systems already provide mechanisms for addressing misconduct and poor performance. Rather than enhancing accountability, this rule would destabilize agencies and expose civil servants to undue political pressure and retaliation.

I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule and protect the values of fairness, stability, and expertise that have long defined our civil service.

attachment_text:
April 23, 2025
Office of Personnel Management
1900 E Street NW
Washington, DC 20415-1000
Re: RIN 3206-AO80, “Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil
Service”
Dear OPM,
I am a career regulatory analyst in the “Office of Policy” of a federal agency with over 10 years
of experience in my current position. As one of the 50,000 federal employees who could lose my
job as a consequence of Schedule Policy/Career, I strongly oppose this rulemaking. Despite
OPM’s assurances to the contrary, I fear that officials in the current administration, or in a future
administration, will exploit Schedule Policy/Career to facilitate “mass head-count reductions in
the federal bureaucracy.”1
Given my experience, I am under no illusions that anything I say will persuade OPM to abandon
its implementation of amended Executive Order 13957 and Schedule Policy/Career. Indeed,
OPM has telegraphed that a reversal isn’t happening, asserting that it “must comport with”
Executive Order 13957 and that “[d]eclining to help the President execute this directive would be
a dereliction of OPM’s statutory duty.”2 Fair enough; it would be unrealistic to expect OPM to
second-guess an executive order issued by the current President. Accordingly, feds like me will
pin our hopes on the judicial branch, which will independently assess whether the Trump
administration’s novel reinterpretation of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 is the “best
reading” of that statute under Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo, 144 S. Ct. 2244, 2266
(2024).3
While the outcome of this rulemaking may be preordained, I have written this comment for one
important purpose. Taking advantage of the candor afforded by anonymity, I hope to refute the
disparaging suspicion of federal employees at the heart of Executive Order 14171—not only to
underscore that this initiative is unnecessary, but to convey to Trump administration officials that
1 Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, The DOGE Plan to Reform Government, Wall Street Journal (Nov.
20, 2024), https://www.wsj.com/opinion/musk-and-ramaswamy-the-doge-plan-to-reform-government-
supreme-court-guidance-end-executive-power-grab-fa51c020https://www.wsj.com/opinion/musk-and-
ramaswamy-the-doge-plan-to-reform-government-supreme-court-guidance-end-executive-power-grab-
fa51c020.
2 90 FR 17200, 17218.
3 As a regulatory analyst, it would be supremely ironic if the Loper Bright decision ends up saving my
job.
1
they can trust in the capability and professionalism of career policy staff. Whether you believe it
or not, we are here to help you.
However, trust is a two-way street, and OPM has done much to diminish its credibility in the
initial months of this administration.4 To the extent OPM is sincere in promising that “employees
who faithfully perform their jobs to the best of their ability have little to fear from Schedule
Policy/Career,”5 I urge OPM to implement meaningful safeguards beyond those included in its
NPRM—in particular, language that would prohibit the arbitrary firing or mass firing of
Schedule Policy/Career employees. Such safeguards would demonstrate OPM’s sincerity about
the stated intent of amended Executive Order 13957—i.e., holding bad actors accountable—
while mitigating some of its harms.
A Solution in Search of a Problem
Before getting into the details of the NPRM, I wish to share my perspective as a federal
employee who will likely be reclassified into Schedule Policy/Career, retaining my anonymity
for obvious reasons. For context, I previously commented in support of OPM’s 2024 rule and
was quoted at length in the preamble of that rule.6
As I described in my earlier comment, I am a GS-13 regulatory analyst who works in the “Office
of Policy” of a prominent federal agency. For better or worse, my agency engages in some of the
most contentious policy work in the federal government. For example, my agency’s policy
priorities change dramatically depending on the political party in charge of the Presidency. Our
rulemakings typically attract thousands of comments and have been the subject of Congressional
committee hearings. Adverse stakeholders challenge our rules and sub-regulatory guidance in
court, with disputes occasionally reaching the U.S. Supreme Court. My “substantive
participation” in this contested policy work is important and exciting,7 but given its sensitivity, I
am scrupulous to maintain the effort, professionalism, and objectivity expected of a taxpayer-
funded federal employee.
As a career analyst, I have worked closely and successfully with political appointees under the
Obama, Trump, and Biden administrations to issue regulations and policy guidance consistent
with the policy priorities of those administrations. Naturally, I have personal opinions about the
policy work I do, and I sometimes disagree with my politically appointed leaders about specific
4 See, e.g., Eric Katz, As Re-Firings Begin, Judge Demands Trump Administration Tell Probationary
Employees They Were Not Let Go for Poor Performance, Politico (April 21, 2025), https://
www.politico.com/news/2025/02/27/opm-firing-probationary-federal-agency-employees-judge-
ruling-00206615; Billy Mitchell, OPM Quietly Swapped Out Privacy Assessment for Governmentwide
Email System Central to Ongoing Litigation, FedScoop (March 3, 2025), https://fedscoop.com/opm-
email-privacy-assessment-swap-ongoing-litigation/.
5 90 FR 17218.
6 See 89 FR 25001 (Comment 3195).
7 E.O. 13957, sec. 5(c)(i).
2
policies or projects. In fact, robust civil service protections have empowered me—and,
collectively, my coworkers and other career employees—to occasionally share policy
recommendations or serious concerns with agency leadership, which sometimes results in our
leadership changing course. This is a perfectly normal and healthy process, as career civil
servants are supposed to provide candid deliberative advice to the politically appointed leaders
who ultimately make the decisions. As OPM continues to recognize,8 candid internal feedback
from career policy staff helps to ensure that regulatory changes and other policy initiatives are
maximally effective, sustainable, and legally defensible.
At the same time, I and other career federal employees certainly understand that we are not the
decisionmakers. Elections in a democracy have consequences, and it is entirely appropriate for
agencies to pursue the policy preferences of the elected President who appoints its leaders. This
is widely understood by all federal employees, who typically go above and beyond Hatch Act
requirements to refrain from appearing politically biased whether we’re on or off the clock.
Speaking personally, I have often worked to delay, withdraw, rescind, and/or replace rules that I
helped a previous administration to promulgate. Occasionally, I have drafted preamble language
rebutting the very same language that I personally authored years before in an earlier
rulemaking. I have also proactively “pitched” policy ideas to agency leadership in every
Presidential administration, including in this administration. In fact, I and my coworkers have
already brainstormed numerous ideas for regulatory relief consistent with the deregulatory aims
of Executive Orders 14192 and 14219.9
Given this experience, I am incredulous at OPM’s assertion that policy resistance is “a
widespread phenomenon.”10 This assertion is a reversal from OPM’s findings last year,11 and it
flies in the face of my personal experience. Sensationalist claims about a widespread “deep state”
or “resistance” within the federal civil service simply do not reflect reality. For example, if there
truly was widespread “policy resistance” against the Trump administration among the 50,000
employees who might be reclassified into Schedule Policy/Career, one would expect ubiquitous
leaks about agency rulemakings and other sensitive policy initiatives to news outlets and adverse
stakeholders. Here, OPM cites to just one example of a career employee ever leaking a policy
document—a draft Presidential executive order promoting classical and traditional architectural
styles in the design of federal buildings.12 This one example, involving a seemingly trivial policy
issue, does not establish that policy resistance is a “widespread” phenomenon.13
8 See 90 FR 17208 (“Career staff critiques, especially those coming from a political perspective that
differs from political appointees, ultimately strengthens policymaking and produces better agency
decisions.”).
9 See 90 FR 9065 (Executive Order 14192); 90 FR 10583 (Executive Order 14219).
10 90 FR 17194.
11 89 FR 25000 (“OPM does not agree that employing civil servants … thwarts the agenda of any
President, and [such assertions] lack any well-founded support.”).
12 90 FR 17193 n. 151.
13 To be clear, I do not condone the actions of that apparently disgruntled architect.
3
The truth is that, like me, the overwhelming majority of career staff respect the integrity of the
policymaking process and the importance of deferring to our Presidentially-appointed leaders.
OPM’s citation to unscientific poll results and a handful of clickbait articles do not make a
persuasive case to the contrary.
In sum, Schedule Policy/Career appears to be a solution in search of a problem. I am not opposed
to holding bad actors accountable, but I have never witnessed or heard about insubordination or
“policy resistance” at my agency of the kind imagined in the NPRM. So, as a threshold matter, I
disagree that there is a problem serious enough to justify stripping civil service protections from
me and 50,000 other federal employees.
Weak Protections and Hollow Assurances
Section 6 of amended Executive Order 13957 provides that “[e]mployees in or applicants for
Schedule Policy/Career positions are not required to personally or politically support the current
President or the policies of the current administration,” and separately instructs agencies to
“establish rules to prohibit the same personnel practices prohibited by [5 U.S.C. 2302(b)] with
respect to any employee or applicant for employment in Schedule Policy/Career of the excepted
service.”14 Additionally, amended Executive Order 13957 deviates from the original Executive
Order 13957 by designating the new schedule as “Schedule Policy/Career” rather than “Schedule
F”—ostensibly to rebut “misinformation” that the administration will use the new schedule as “a
means of converting career positions to political positions.”15
These protections are better than nothing, but they seem functionally unenforceable. As OPM
noted last year:
Once hirings and firings are at-will … [an] employee might not have an
entitlement to written notice of the reasons for [an] adverse action, an opportunity
to respond, or a written decision. Nor would the decision generally be appealable.
It would thus be, at a minimum, difficult for employees to protect themselves
from actions based on political beliefs or party allegiance because no cause (or
evidence) would be required prior to such an action. Under Schedule F, because
such an employee would be at-will, the employer would need to give little or no
reason prior to a termination. In short, Schedule F leaves innumerable ways for
politics to factor into these traditionally merit-based decisions in a manner that
would be difficult to detect or remedy.16
Even in its new NPRM, OPM acknowledges the risk that “some [agency] officials” may “treat
Schedule Policy/Career positions as noncareer positions” and fire employees for perceived
14 E.O. 13957, sec. 6.
15 90 FR 17200.
16 89 FR 24994 (citations omitted).
4
political disloyalty.17 In response, OPM replies that it will “be heavily involved in the
implementation of Schedule Policy/Career” and “if necessary … can recommend additional
measures to prevent abuses.”18 Respectfully, these vague assurances are not good enough. OPM
is the federal agency with the duty to implement amended Executive Order 13957 and should not
wait for predictable harms to materialize before merely “recommend[ing]” solutions. Indeed,
section 6(a) of amended Executive Order 13957 instructs that “agencies”—including OPM—
“shall establish rules to prohibit [certain] personnel practices” against Schedule Policy/Career
employees,19 but OPM’s NPRM fails to include any language about prohibited personnel
practices in the proposed reg text for 5 CFR 213.3501.20 At minimum, OPM should fix that
oversight in its final rule.
Of course, the bigger problem is that nothing in OPM’s NPRM or in the express text of amended
Executive Order 13957 will protect Schedule Policy/Career employees from mass firings. As
OPM notes, “placing … employees into Schedule Policy/Career makes them functionally at-
will.”21 Thus, as long as agencies do not discriminate when they fire individual employees,
agency heads will be newly empowered to quickly fire large groups of federal employees for no
reason at all—as many as 50,000 across the federal government, according to OPM's estimate in
the NPRM.22 Contemplating the protections afforded to Schedule Policy/Career employees, one
is reminded of Joseph Stalin’s infamous distinction between tragedies and statistics.
In a tacit acknowledgement of concerns that Schedule Policy/Career could be used for mass
firings, OPM assures that “employees who faithfully perform their jobs to the best of their ability
have little to fear from Schedule Policy/Career … [as] agencies have strong incentives not to
dismiss employees who are competently performing their assigned duties.”23 Of particular
relevance to me, OPM aptly notes that “drafting regulations and guidance … are complex tasks
that require considerable experience with the subject matter and technical procedures” which
“[f]ew newly hired employees—career or noncareer—can do … effectively,” concluding that “a
President who wants agencies to implement his policies has strong incentives not to dismiss
experienced regulation writers who are performing timely and quality work, no matter their
personal political affiliation.”24 Relatedly, OPM asserts that “the President and his appointees
have additional incentivizes to maintain a career workforce that contains a diversity of views and
opinions … [as] frank and fearless advice to agency leadership … helps agencies make better
decisions, which the President and agency leaders value.”25
17 90 FR 17209.
18 Id.
19 E.O. 13957, sec. 6(a) (emphasis added).
20 See 90 FR 17222.
21 90 FR 17218.
22 90 FR 17220.
23 90 FR 17218.
24 90 FR 17208.
25 90 FR 17208-09.
5
I wholeheartedly agree with OPM’s statements quoted in the paragraph above, but they ring
hollow in light of other actions and statements from the Trump administration exhibiting extreme
hostility towards federal employees,26 including from President Trump. For example, in
describing his regulatory freeze order issued on January 20, 2025, President Trump deviated
from prepared remarks to quip that “Most of those bureaucrats are being fired, they’re gone.
Should be all of them, but some sneak through, but we have to live with a couple I guess.”27
In this context, in the absence of specific safeguards to prevent us from being fired for arbitrary
reasons, OPM’s assurances to career staff in the NPRM feels like gaslighting from the villain in a
predictable horror film. “I’m so happy to have you for dinner! Would you mind stepping down
into that soundproof basement?”
Conclusion
While civil service protections are important for all federal employees, they are particularly
important for career policy staff, who perform important work for considerably less pay than
what they could earn in the private sector.28 Candor is key to our jobs, and civil service
protections are key to our candor. Unfortunately, amended Executive Order 13957 and new
Schedule Policy/Career will strip civil service protections from thousands of federal employees
who are already weary and demoralized—an extremely misguided policy move. Among other
harms, the new Schedule Policy/Career will:
• jeopardize the careers and livelihoods of thousands of federal employees;
• deter career staff from providing candid deliberative advice for fear of perceived
“resistance;” and
• damage government efforts to recruit, hire, and retain talent, thereby reducing the speed
and effectiveness of the federal government.
26 See Executive Order 14210 of February 11, 2025, 90 FR 9669 (instructing agencies to “promptly
undertake preparations to initiate large-scale reductions in force”); see also, e.g., Molly Redden and Andy
Kroll, “Put Them in Trauma”: Inside a Key MAGA Leader’s Plans for a New Trump Agenda, ProPublica
(Oct. 24, 2024), https://www.propublica.org/article/video-donald-trump-russ-vought-center-renewing-
america-maga; Taylor Giorno, ‘We Are Terrified’: Musk Puts USAID Through ‘Wood Chipper,’ The Hill
(Feb. 3, 2025), https://www.thehill.com/policy/technology/5122676-usaid-shutdown-elon-musk-doge/.
27 See https://www.youtube.com/live/SzozeHjyLv4?t=656s; see also Erich Wagner, Trump: Agencies
Should Fire 'All' Bureaucrats, Government Executive (Jan. 20, 2025), https://www.govexec.com/
workforce/2025/01/trump-agencies-should-fire-all-bureaucrats/402353/.
28 For example, according to the Congressional Budget Office, “Federal workers with a professional
degree or doctorate—about 10 percent of the federal workforce—earn about 29 percent less, on average,
than their private-sector counterparts.” Congressional Budget Office, “Comparing the Compensation of
Federal and Private-Sector Employees in 2022,” (April 2024) at 1, https://www.cbo.gov/publication/
60235.
6
Additional safeguards—such as a language prohibiting the arbitrary firing or mass firing of
Schedule Policy/Career employees—could mitigate some of these harms, but this
administration’s damage to the federal workforce has already been immense. I don’t fault other

title: Comment from Csaba  Skultety
comment:
As a United States citizen and spouse of a federal employee, I am very much opposed to this new regulation. The federal workforce has protections in place in order to keep employees from being fired whenever a new administration is elected. The proposed regulation assumes that many federal employees are lazy, incompetent, or otherwise unfit to do their jobs and therefore proposes relaxing the protections currently in place in order to remove these employees from the federal workforce. However, this presumption is false. Most federal employees are hard-working Americans who have dedicated their lives to serving the public. They work just as hard as anyone in the private sector. 

The regulation pretends to care about performance, accountability, and responsiveness, but completely ignores the fact that almost every single agency in the government is being downsized already and performance and responsiveness will, in fact, suffer because of those downsizing efforts. Therefore it feels like this regulation actually has very little to do with performance, accountability, and responsiveness, and more to do with replacing employees who do not voice support for the administration's policies. Replacing knowledgeable, hard working people with yes-men, will not make the government more responsive or performant.
