title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
As a dedicated scientist and small business owner committed to the principles of evidence-based research and the mission of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), I am deeply concerned about the proposed rule titled "Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" (FR Document: 2025-06904). While enhancing accountability within the civil service is a commendable goal, certain aspects of this proposal could inadvertently compromise the nonpartisan foundation essential to scientific endeavors and public trust.

The proposal suggests reclassifying policy-influencing positions into a new "Schedule Policy/Career" category, rendering them at-will roles exempt from standard adverse action procedures and appeals. Although these positions are described as remaining career jobs filled on a nonpartisan basis, the at-will nature inherently introduces a vulnerability to political influence. This is particularly concerning for scientific agencies like the NIH, where policy decisions must be grounded in rigorous, unbiased research rather than shifting political agendas.

The ability to remove employees without the usual procedural safeguards could deter scientists from pursuing innovative or controversial research topics, fearing repercussions tied to political sensitivities rather than scientific merit. Such an environment risks stifling scientific progress and undermines the credibility of institutions that rely on objective analysis to inform public health policies.

To preserve the integrity of scientific research and maintain public confidence in our institutions, I urge a reconsideration of the provisions that allow for at-will employment in policy-influencing positions. Implementing robust protections against political interference is crucial to ensure that science remains a guiding force for the public good, free from partisan pressures.

title: Comment from Dave Phox
comment:
I’m firmly against bringing back or creating anything like “Schedule F” for federal employees. This kind of policy would deal a serious blow to the merit-based civil service system that has kept our federal workforce professional and nonpartisan for well over 100 years.

Let’s be clear—this idea goes completely against the spirit of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883. That law was passed to stop the old “spoils system,” where jobs were handed out as political favors, and instead establish a system based on merit. Schedule F would do the opposite—it would allow large numbers of career civil servants, especially those involved in policy, to be reclassified and fired without cause. That opens the door wide to political interference and hiring based on loyalty rather than qualifications or expertise.

It also violates the due process rights federal workers currently have. Under current law (5 U.S.C. § 7513), career employees are supposed to be protected from unjust termination—they deserve fair procedures and a valid reason before being removed. Schedule F throws those protections out the window, weakening both job security and the ability of employees to offer honest, expert advice—even when it’s not politically convenient.

There’s also the issue of OPM’s responsibility. The Office of Personnel Management is legally required (5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq.) to uphold the merit system principles. Schedule F would force OPM to work against its own mission by placing political pressure on career staff, disrupting the stability and impartiality of federal programs that are meant to last across administrations.

Bottom line: Schedule F is a dangerous idea. It threatens good governance, undermines the independence of the civil service, and chips away at the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to stand firm against any attempt to revive or implement it.

title: Comment from Jay Moore
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification

comment:
My comment is in regards to 2025-06904 (90 FR 17182).  I believe this is a ill-advised proposal which must not be advanced further.

Briefly, I strongly believe that policy should be informed by good science.  However, science should never be driven by policy goals.  Science should be driven by seeking truth.  Thus, I believe that discretionary authority in agency grantmaking driven by policy concerns is anti-scientific. Replacing civil servants with political appointees would be detrimental to seeking truth.  I urge you NOT to advance this proposal.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the Office of Personnel Management’s proposed rule (Docket OPM-2025-0004; RIN 3206-AO80) to create a new “Schedule Policy/Career” excepted-service category for policy-influencing positions. I strongly oppose the retroactive application of this rule to current incumbents and instead urge OPM to limit any reclassification to positions as they become vacant and to new hires going forward.

Career employees have accumulated a property interest in their civil-service status, including pre-removal notice, hearing rights, and MSPB appeals under Chapters 43 and 75 of Title 5, U.S. Code. Stripping these protections en masse violates the Fifth Amendment’s guarantee that no person shall be deprived of “life, liberty, or property, without due process of law,” and the Supreme Court has recognized that significant employment-related entitlements constitute such property interests. Retaining protections for incumbents while applying Schedule Policy/Career only prospectively would honor those settled expectations without undermining accountability goals.

Congress narrowly authorized exceptions to civil-service protections for “positions determined to be of a confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character”—i.e., political appointees—not career incumbents. Section 7511(b)(2) of Title 5 confirms that exclusions from Chapter 75 attach to the position’s nature, not to who occupies it. OPM’s attempt to remove protections from existing incumbents therefore exceeds its regulatory authority under the Civil Service Reform Act.

The Civil Service Reform Act requires that any exception to competitive-service requirements be “necessary” and warranted by “conditions of good administration” (5 U.S.C. § 3302). Retroactively sweeping in current employees en masse cannot satisfy that strict standard, as it neither targets proven instances of serious misconduct nor ensures rigorous, case-by-case determinations by individual agency heads.

Under the APA, rescinding or revising existing regulations requires the same notice-and-comment procedures used to promulgate them (5 U.S.C. § 553). Yet the proposed rule attempts to render inoperative the Biden-era regulations via a brief NPRM rather than full, reasoned analysis of thousands of comments and empirical data. This approach risks arbitrary and capricious decision-making prohibited by APA § 706.

I respectfully oppose the entire concept of creating a Schedule Policy/Career excepted-service category, the proposed rule itself, and the accompanying Executive Order. Establishing an at-will layer over career positions politicizes roles that Congress intended to remain nonpartisan, undermines merit-system principles, and eliminates foundational due-process safeguards for thousands of federal employees.

For these reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw the retroactive reclassification component and the broader Schedule Policy/Career initiative. Civil-service protections should remain intact for current incumbents, with any new accountability measures applied only prospectively to vacated positions and new hires.

title: Comment from Amanda Rabinowitz
comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to express strong opposition to any proposal or policy that would replace nonpartisan civil servants involved in the National Institutes of Health (NIH) grantmaking process with political appointees. The integrity and effectiveness of our nation's biomedical research enterprise depend on the independence, objectivity, and expertise of the scientists and career professionals who oversee funding decisions.

Scientific research must remain guided by evidence, peer review, and the pursuit of knowledge — not political agendas. Allowing political appointees to exert influence over grant allocation risks undermining the credibility of the NIH, compromising the merit-based review process, and discouraging innovative and essential research that may not align with short-term policy goals or partisan interests.

The NIH has long stood as a global leader in scientific excellence precisely because it has maintained a clear separation between science and politics. Civil servants bring deep institutional knowledge, continuity, and a commitment to upholding rigorous standards. Replacing them with individuals whose roles may be shaped by political considerations would erode public trust and diminish the quality of the science that NIH supports.

I urge the NIH and all relevant decisionmakers to safeguard the independence of the grantmaking process and to reject any proposals that would politicize this cornerstone of American science.

title: Comment from Steven Mann
comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

I strongly oppose the proposed rule that would establish a new Schedule Policy/Career employment category. This rule raises serious legal concerns, including direct conflict with the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) and well-established constitutional due process protections for federal employees.

1. Violation of the Civil Service Reform Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 2301–2302)
The CSRA enshrines the merit system principles as the cornerstone of federal employment. Specifically, 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(2) states that "all employees and applicants for employment should receive fair and equitable treatment in all aspects of personnel management… with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional rights."

Furthermore, 5 U.S.C. § 7513 mandates that adverse actions, including removals and suspensions, be carried out only "for such cause as will promote the efficiency of the service," and requires advance notice, representation, and an opportunity to respond. The proposed Schedule Policy/Career classification unlawfully circumvents these statutory protections by permitting at-will removal without these required procedures.

2. Undermining Constitutional Due Process Rights
The U.S. Supreme Court has recognized in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill, 470 U.S. 532 (1985), that public employees with a property interest in their continued employment are entitled to due process before termination. By designating career civil servants as at-will employees and removing their appeal rights, the rule violates this constitutional guarantee.

Even policy-influencing roles do not lose their entitlement to basic procedural protections when filled through competitive, nonpolitical appointments. Attempting to redefine these roles to strip away due process is a de facto repeal of civil service rights without Congressional authorization.

3. Exceeds OPM’s Statutory Authority
The proposed rule attempts to unilaterally reclassify large swaths of the workforce and redefine fundamental aspects of federal employment. This oversteps the regulatory authority granted to the Office of Personnel Management under 5 U.S.C. § 1103, which does not permit wholesale reclassification of employees to evade the merit-based protections mandated by Congress.

Courts have been skeptical of agencies attempting to bypass clear statutory protections through rulemaking. As noted in Util. Air Regulatory Grp. v. EPA, 573 U.S. 302, 324 (2014), "an agency may not rewrite clear statutory terms to suit its own sense of how the statute should operate."

4. Risk of Politicization and Retaliation
The proposed rule’s stated justification includes removing employees who “undermine the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives.” This vague and subjective standard, when combined with at-will status, invites abuse and may be used to purge qualified employees for ideological reasons, not performance—a direct violation of 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(10), which prohibits discrimination based on political affiliation.

Conclusion:
The proposed rule is not only bad policy but also likely unlawful. It threatens to erode the apolitical nature of the civil service, bypasses core legal protections enshrined in the CSRA and the Constitution, and grants the Executive Branch undue power over career personnel.

I urge OPM to withdraw this proposal in its entirety.

title: Comment from Ben Williams
comment:
I am commenting on the proposed rule by the Office of Personnel Management
Docket ID OPM-2025-0004
RIN 3206-AO80

I am strongly opposed to this proposed rule change. Civil service protections are in place for a reason, to ensure that we attract and retain experienced federal workers. Our civil workers have specific expertise and experience and have a sense of history, having worked for multiple administrations. This knowledge is valuable to the offices they hold and to provide context for why certain regulations, decisions, protections were carried out a certain way in the past. We have seen over the past few months haphazard cutting of staff. AI generated letters that informed probationary staff they were fired for "performance reasons" regardless of their actual performance, resulting in us firing those who's only fault was being recently hired or promoted.

I am deeply troubled by this move by OPM. Employees can already be removed for poor performance or for misconduct. Their rights under chapter 45 and chapter 75 should not be removed. They should have the right to appeal when accused. This rule change gives way too much power to the executive branch for whomever is in office. Please keep in place the existing protections and do not instill schedule F changes proposed in Docket ID OPM-2025-0004.

title: Comment from Tim Mobley
comment:
I strongly oppose the reimplementation or expansion of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This policy would fundamentally undermine the merit-based civil service system that has protected the integrity, professionalism, and nonpartisan nature of our federal workforce for over a century.

Schedule F would allow for the mass reclassification of career federal employees into a category that strips them of key civil service protections, making them vulnerable to politically motivated hiring and firing. This would not only destabilize agencies but also erode the institutional knowledge and continuity that are critical to effective governance.

Public servants are expected to carry out the law impartially and based on expertise, not political loyalty. Creating a large class of at-will employees risks politicizing the federal workforce, discouraging talented individuals from public service, and damaging public trust in government institutions.

Our country depends on a professional civil service that is insulated from political whims. Schedule F is a direct threat to that principle. I urge decision-makers to reject any efforts to revive or expand this harmful policy.

comment:
Choosing staff based on party loyalty is a horrible way to run an agency, company, or government.  I certainly prefer the folks who are in charge of nuclear facilities to be qualified with years of experience vs. the equivalent of the boss' nephew running the show.  Please use common sense.  While I have no objections reducing government waste, and removing people who are not doing their jobs competently, putting unqualified Trump loyalists in place of qualified employees is a recipe for disaster, and a sure fire way to move our country further down the road of authoritarianism.

As we have seen almost every day since the president came into office, his directives are outside the law, and in NO way, shape, or form, should supersede an employee's ethics, morals, or responsibilities.  

This rule is awful, and should be shredded as soon as humanly possible.

title: Comment from Benjamin  Peracchio
comment:
I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed rule (OPM-2025-0004-0001) that would reintroduce a Schedule F-type classification in the federal workforce. This policy is misguided, legally questionable, and threatens the nonpartisan integrity of the civil service.

First, the proposal undermines the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. § 7511), which limits the exception of civil service protections to a narrow category of positions that are “confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating.” The proposed rule goes far beyond this intent by opening the door to the mass reclassification of career civil servants without sufficient statutory authority.

Second, this proposal raises serious constitutional concerns. Federal employees possess a property interest in their continued employment, and reclassifying positions to at-will status without individualized due process may violate the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. As highlighted in Kloeckner v. Solis, 568 U.S. 41 (2012), federal employees are entitled to meaningful procedural protections and access to redress. Schedule F undermines those principles.

Third, this rule would weaken merit system principles enshrined in federal law, including the requirement that hiring and firing decisions be made based on competence and performance, not political loyalty. The nonpartisan, apolitical character of the civil service is a cornerstone of American democracy and public trust.

Reinstating Schedule F would politicize career appointments, damage morale, erode institutional expertise, and violate long-standing legal frameworks designed to ensure government accountability and professionalism.

I urge OPM to withdraw this proposal in its entirety

title: Comment from Aubrey Grave
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal will not improve performance, accountability or responsiveness. The proposed action threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

The creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

The vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
It is important to have a nonpartisan civil service that continues its mission in accordance with law, not one that is overly name of political appointees who change with each administration. The US, over decades and centuries, has built a current structure that generally works today. Where there are problems, they should be fixed within the system, such as in a manner in accordance with law, such as by increased use of inspectors general.

This proposed change will not have the effect of improving the civil service, but rather, will worsen it to favor the current administration's appointees based on their politics, not based on their ability. Unless we assume that one administration will be in power forever, which would not be a sign of a healthy democracy, this proposed change will lead to a less effective civil service that changes from administration to administration and does not build up expertise in service of the country as a whole.

title: Comment from Ian Towers
comment:
The Office of Personnel Management’s (OPM) proposed rule, OPM-2025-0004-0001, amending 5 CFR Part 731, delegates authority to the OPM Director to make suitability determinations and issue removal directives for federal employees based on post-appointment conduct. This aligns with the reintroduction of Schedule F, rebranded as Schedule Policy/Career in 2025, aiming to reclassify career employees as at-will, stripping them of merit-based protections. As a union-minded scholar, I oppose this rule for its assault on meritocracy, due process, and labor rights, threatening the integrity of the federal civil service.
The federal civil service, rooted in the Pendleton Act of 1883, ensures competence and impartiality, shielding employees from political pressures. The proposed rule undermines this by centralizing authority in the OPM Director, mandating agency compliance within five workdays, and aligning with Schedule F’s agenda to politicize the workforce. Schedule F, introduced in 2020 and revoked in 2021, sought to reclassify employees in policy roles as at-will, enabling dismissals without cause. Its 2025 revival, as noted on X, risks replacing career professionals with loyalists, prioritizing politics over expertise.
The rule’s vague criteria for “unsuitable” conduct invite abuse, allowing subjective or politicized removals. This contradicts merit-based principles, where decisions should reflect performance, not loyalty. Centralizing authority bypasses agencies’ contextual knowledge, eroding the decentralized structure that ensures fairness. Historically, suitability determinations balanced agency needs with employee rights; this rule tilts toward arbitrary discipline, undermining trust in governance.
Due process, a cornerstone of labor law, is gutted by the rule’s five-day compliance mandate, limiting employees’ ability to challenge decisions via the Merit Systems Protection Board or unions. This disproportionately harms unionized workers, whose collective bargaining agreements protect against unjust actions. The rule’s silence on union involvement signals a deliberate sidelining of labor, chilling federal workers’ ability to engage in union activities or exercise First Amendment rights. Such ambiguity risks targeting employees for non-job-related conduct, fostering fear and compliance over independence.
The rule operationalizes Schedule F by enabling rapid dismissals of employees deemed misaligned with political priorities. X posts highlight Schedule F as a “dangerous” politicization of public service, undermining agencies’ impartiality. This institutional capture prioritizes partisan agendas, demoralizing workers and reducing expertise in critical areas like public health or environmental protection. The sociological impact—eroding trust in institutions—threatens democratic governance, as politicized agencies may neglect equitable policymaking.
Economically, the rule destabilizes federal workers, many supporting families and communities. At-will employment creates uncertainty, disproportionately affecting marginalized groups vulnerable to discriminatory “suitability” interpretations. Socially, a loyalist-driven civil service may prioritize political goals over public needs, exacerbating inequalities in healthcare, poverty, or environmental justice. This betrays the civil service’s oath to the Constitution, not any administration.
The rule’s alignment with Schedule F demands its withdrawal. It threatens the meritocratic foundation of the civil service, erodes labor protections, and risks long-term harm to governance. If OPM proceeds, it must: 1) reaffirm merit-based criteria; 2) ensure robust due process with extended timelines and appeals; 3) consult unions to preserve bargaining rights; 4) reject Schedule F’s politicization; and 5) enhance transparency through public hearings.
Federal employees deserve a system that upholds fairness, not one that sacrifices them to political expediency. The civil service’s integrity hinges on rejecting this rule and recommitting to merit, impartiality, and labor rights.

Citations
	•	White House, Strengthening the Suitability and Fitness of the Federal Workforce, 2025.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I oppose the proposed regulation OPM-2025-0004, which seeks to reclassify certain federal positions into the new “Schedule Policy/Career” category. This change would strip civil service protections from approximately 50,000 federal employees, making them at-will and vulnerable to dismissal without the standard due process. Such a move threatens the merit-based foundation of the federal workforce, opening the door to politicization and undermining the nonpartisan execution of government functions.

By removing established safeguards, the regulation risks creating an environment where career professionals can be terminated for political reasons, rather than for legitimate performance issues. This not only jeopardizes the impartiality of federal agencies but also deters qualified individuals from public service due to job insecurity. The proposed rule’s potential to erode institutional knowledge and expertise could lead to inefficiencies and a decline in the quality of public services.

Furthermore, the lack of clear criteria for reclassification raises concerns about arbitrary or discriminatory implementation. The regulation’s broad scope and the significant number of positions affected necessitate thorough scrutiny and debate. I urge reconsideration of this proposal and the upholding of the principles of a fair, competent, and apolitical civil service.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

comment: I am concerned about the implications for the new proposed rule "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service." title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am firmly opposed to any effort to implement or reinstate the “Schedule F” classification within the federal workforce. This measure would fundamentally erode the merit-based civil service system that has ensured a professional, nonpartisan federal government for over a hundred years.



To begin with, Schedule F runs directly counter to the intent of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was designed to dismantle the spoils system by instituting merit-based hiring for federal roles. Reclassifying large numbers of career civil servants—especially those involved in policy-making or analysis—would expose them to dismissal without cause. This creates a clear path for politically driven employment decisions, contradicting the core tenet of a politically neutral civil service outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which safeguards employment decisions from partisan influence.



Additionally, the broad and ambiguous criteria for placing employees under Schedule F are inconsistent with the due process rights granted under 5 U.S.C. § 7513. That statute requires justified cause and procedural fairness in disciplinary actions involving federal employees. Removing these protections would not only compromise accountability but also stifle open dialogue and expert input within agencies, ultimately weakening the effectiveness of public administration.



The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), as governed by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., has a duty to uphold the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F would run contrary to this obligation, introducing undue political interference into a system meant to be impartial and resilient across changing administrations.



In summary, Schedule F represents a serious threat to the integrity, independence, and legal foundations of our civil service. I strongly urge both the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory action aimed at bringing this classification back into practice.

title: Comment from Elizabeth Husmann
comment:
I’m strongly against bringing back or creating anything like the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. It’s a serious threat to the merit-based civil service system that’s helped keep our government professional and nonpartisan for over 100 years.

Let’s be real—Schedule F basically goes against everything the Pendleton Act of 1883 was designed to fix. That law was put in place to stop the old “spoils system” and make sure federal jobs are awarded based on qualifications, not political connections. But Schedule F would let a huge number of career civil servants—especially folks involved in policy work—get reclassified and possibly fired without any real cause. That opens the door to political loyalty tests, which totally goes against the whole idea of a neutral, professional civil service. Federal law (5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8)) clearly says hiring and firing should be based on merit, not politics.

It also raises big red flags when it comes to due process. The rules in 5 U.S.C. § 7513 are there to make sure career employees can’t just be fired on a whim—they’re supposed to have protections and a fair process. Taking that away from thousands of federal workers doesn’t just hurt morale, it could seriously chill open debate and expert input inside agencies. That’s bad news for effective government.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is supposed to uphold those merit system values (per 5 U.S.C. § 1101 and beyond), and Schedule F would force them to go in the exact opposite direction. It puts unfair political pressure on career employees and threatens the stability of programs that need to work across different administrations.

comment: Not hyperbole: enact this plan and be prepared to endure a post-America collapse of basic institutions and systems; loss of institutional knowledge, cronyism, fraud, waste, and abuse, that will have second and third order effects of loss of trust of institutional norms, leading to a total collapse of our Country in very short order. comment: I am a federally funded cognitive scientist (NSF and DARPA) and US citizen who moved to the UK in April 2024. I continue to spend time and vote in New York State. Grants for scientific research should be administered by scientists as they are best qualified to understand what areas are scientific priorities now and which are likely to become important in the future. While policy goals should inform what funding programs are offered, grantmaking should be separate from policy. Other countries understand this, and if America replaces scientific control of grant-making with political control, those nations will rapidly out-compete us in STEM.

title: Comment from Jacob Garrett
comment:
I unequivocally oppose the implementation—or any effort toward the reinstatement—of the “Schedule F” classification within the federal civil service. Such a proposal represents a fundamental threat to the merit-based framework that has sustained a professional and politically neutral federal workforce for well over a century.

At its core, Schedule F subverts the principles established by the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, legislation specifically designed to dismantle the spoils system and replace it with a system grounded in meritocratic hiring and retention. By authorizing the wholesale reclassification of career civil servants—particularly those engaged in policy formulation or analysis—Schedule F effectively enables arbitrary dismissals untethered from cause or performance. This erodes the apolitical nature of the federal workforce, directly contravening the mandates articulated in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which codify the requirement that federal personnel decisions be guided solely by merit and shielded from partisan interference.

Furthermore, the broad and imprecise criteria for Schedule F designation pose significant due process concerns. The protections afforded under 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which guarantee cause-based removal and procedural safeguards for career federal employees, are effectively nullified under this classification. Such a shift not only compromises individual rights but also has chilling implications for the internal functioning of federal agencies, discouraging candid professional advice and dissent—both of which are essential to sound policymaking and institutional integrity.

The proposed classification also places the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in direct conflict with its statutory obligations under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., which entrust the agency with the stewardship of the merit system principles. Instituting Schedule F would compel OPM to facilitate politically motivated personnel decisions, thereby undermining the very mission it is charged with upholding.

In sum, the resurrection of Schedule F represents a profound deviation from the foundational tenets of public administration in the United States. It endangers the independence, competence, and continuity of the civil service and invites a return to politicized governance. I urge the administration and the OPM to reject, without reservation, any regulatory initiative aimed at implementing or reviving this deeply troubling classification.

title: Comment from Asheleigh Johnson
comment:
"I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

title: Comment from Ashley Arnold
comment:
As a former federal employee who served in various administrative capacities, I am writing to express my concern and opposition to the proposed rule referenced as OPM-2025-0004-0001. While I fully support the principles of accountability and effective public service, I believe the measures outlined in this proposal risk undermining the merit-based foundation of the civil service.

The current framework already includes established mechanisms for addressing conduct and performance issues. Expanding disciplinary authority or altering due process protections could open the door to inconsistent enforcement, favoritism, or retaliatory practices—particularly in agencies where oversight is limited or unevenly applied.

Moreover, proposals that increase the ease of disciplinary actions without simultaneously reinforcing employee rights and representation are likely to reduce morale and weaken retention, especially in administrative and support roles that are already under-recognized and often overburdened.

I urge OPM to reconsider this approach and instead focus on improving supervisory training, standardizing performance metrics, and investing in supportive structures that foster both accountability and employee development. A balanced system must protect the integrity of public service while upholding the rights and dignity of the workforce.

title: Comment from Emily Kolyvas
comment:

This change threatens the foundational principles of a merit-based, nonpartisan civil service, particularly within critical agencies such as the National Institutes of Health (NIH).​

The potential politicization of roles—including NIH institute directors and program officers—poses a significant risk to the integrity and objectivity of scientific research and public health policy. Implementing Schedule F could lead to the dismissal of experienced, nonpartisan professionals, undermining institutional knowledge and continuity. Such actions would erode public trust in our institutions and compromise the effectiveness of essential government functions.​

I urge the administration to reconsider this proposal and uphold the principles of a professional, nonpartisan civil service that serves the American people with integrity and expertise.

title: Comment from Chris Marshall
comment:
I firmly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees, as it jeopardizes the merit-based civil service system that has sustained a professional and nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.
Proponents of Schedule F argue that it grants the executive branch flexibility in carrying out the President's agenda by making it easier to replace career civil servants who may be resistant to policy changes. However, this flexibility comes at a serious cost. By reclassifying a significant number of career employees—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—and subjecting them to termination without cause, Schedule F risks replacing expertise with political loyalty. This undermines the principle of an apolitical civil service, as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence. An administration’s efficiency cannot come at the expense of the constitutional commitment to impartial governance.
Advocates also claim that Schedule F would improve accountability by removing underperforming employees more easily. Yet the broad and vague criteria for inclusion in Schedule F contradict the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which require cause and procedural safeguards for removing career federal employees. Stripping these protections weakens—not strengthens—accountability. It could discourage employees from voicing dissenting opinions or providing candid expert advice, ultimately harming the effectiveness of government operations.
Additionally, supporters suggest that implementing Schedule F would streamline federal operations by aligning staff more closely with an administration’s goals. But this short-term alignment would come at the expense of long-term stability and continuity in federal programs. The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to uphold merit system principles, would be acting against its statutory mission by implementing Schedule F. The result would be undue political pressure on career professionals, threatening the integrity and effectiveness of federal programs across administrations.
In summary, while Schedule F may appear to offer greater flexibility and efficiency to the executive branch, its adoption poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this harmful classification

I urge the administration to reconsider this proposal and uphold the principles of a professional, nonpartisan civil service that serves the American people with integrity and expertise.

title: Comment from Skylar Martinez
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Concerned Civilian
comment:
As government workers, we have been instructed to stay apolitical in the scope of our duties. Changing the federal workforce to "at will" employment is part of a larger Trump administration push to dramatically shrink the size of government and exert more control over it. 

Is this not against the policies they follow and were hired to complete if the President can fire them if they refuse to advance his policy interests? What happens in four years when a new president is elected and has different interests? How will the government ever be sustainable again? 

The gutting of government agencies is already undermining its effectiveness and this will make things worse. 

I urge OPM to consider this regulation unconstitutional and to not approve.

title: Comment from Hallie Friedman
comment: Do not change Schedule F employees' status. Those who choose to serve our country by using their skills, talents and education by going into government service as opposed to the private sector where they could earn considerably more money should not be penalized. But my opposition to this proposed change is not merely about the individual harm to government employees who might unfairly lose their jobs. No, I am more concerned about the deleterious impact on all of us. Government employees often have specialized and institutional knowledge that is irreplaceable, or at least is very costly to replace. Of course, people should be fired for cause for instance if they've broken regulations or laws or acted unconstitutionally. But changing the the status of government employees just so that they can be fired for no reason at all is hurtful to our entire society -- our health and safety and security.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: During the 19th Century, federal employment was rife with corruption; employees obtained or retained their jobs based not on merit or competence, but on their political affiliation. The Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) established the current merit-based system in the federal workforce, outlining protections and expectations for a federal employee, while also defining exceptions, such as the historically and realistically miniscule group of political employees. The proposed rule seeks to expand "political appointee" to include career employees, stripping them of the protections they have enjoyed since 1978. I am concerned that this rule will inevitably lead to federal employment populated by people retained exclusively for their loyalty or connections to individuals rather than to the mission of supporting all Americans through the government made by the People and for the People. Furthermore, the CSRA does not extend to the President the power to strip career employees of their protections under CSRA, but only political appointees. For the definition of a political appointee, see 5 U.S.C. § 9803(c)(2)(A) "the term 'political appointee' means an employee who holds a position which has been excepted from the competitive service by reason of its confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character", 7 U.S.C § 6992(e)(2)(D) "the term 'political appointee' means an individual occupying a position which has been excepted from the competitive service by reason of its confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character" and 38 U.S.C. § 725(c) "The term 'political appointee' means any employee [...] who holds a position which has been excepted from the competitive service by reason of its confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character." There is extensive legal precedent, with commentary on the spirit and intent of CSRA from the Supreme Court and Congress itself. Under constitutional and statutory interpretation, ultimately Schedule F is unlawful, if politically convenient. It is my hope that our great Government upholds the rule of law and protects our career civil servants so that federal employment does not become like those seen in adversarial countries, where knowing the right person or currying political favor are the sole keys to success and corruption abounds.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I oppose this rule. Not only do I believe this proposed rule to be incredibly dangerous, but it also sets a foreboding precedent for the future regarding what a given administration is allowed to do with its staff. Furthermore, there are a number of well-cited cases that lay out the unconstitutionality of such a rule. I would refer to the commentary of Walter M. Shaub, Jr., former leader of the Federal Office of Government Ethics. I'm not sure if I can find a stronger voice than that regarding the potential dangers and breaches of ethics that this rule represents.

Not to mention that there is extensive historical precedent(Brownlow committee, Hoover Commission) upon which our establishment of a MERIT-BASED system has been built. A rule such as this paves the way for the return of a "spoils system" of patronage, one that we have seen historically to be rife with corruption and hence rightfully done away with.

Especially within the context of an administration that ostensibly claims to favor merit as opposed to inclusion(in fact, this is the stated intent behind many DEI measures and the like), a rule such as this feels very much out of step. As such, I see no reason why a rule such as this should be passed and stand in vehement opposition.

title: Comment from Joshua Driesman
comment:
While I support the goal of enhancing performance and accountability in government, I strongly oppose this rule as written. By creating a new Schedule Policy/Career within the excepted service and exempting those employees from the adverse action procedures and appeals protections under 5 U.S.C. chapters 43 and 75, this proposal fundamentally undermines the nonpartisan merit-based civil service established under the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA).

The CSRA was enacted to ensure that employees are “protected against arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or coercion for partisan political purposes” and to uphold an effective and efficient merit-based civil service (5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)). This proposed rule reverses those principles by designating certain career positions as effectively at-will, subject to removal without meaningful procedural safeguards. This would significantly weaken civil service protections that have been in place for decades, diminishing the neutrality and continuity of our federal workforce.

Additionally, by shifting a broad class of career positions into an at-will category that can be easily reshaped by each incoming administration, this rule risks triggering cyclical, large-scale turnover every four to eight years. Such turnover would deplete institutional knowledge and discourage long-term public service careers. It would also erode the impartiality that is essential to maintaining public trust in the implementation of laws and policies.

Although the proposed rule maintains that these positions will be filled on a nonpartisan basis, the reality is that removing traditional appeal rights and due process protections opens the door to politicized removals and the perception thereof. Even the best-intentioned leaders cannot prevent such perceptions when protections are removed, particularly in politically sensitive policy areas.

In conclusion, while the desire to streamline personnel actions is understandable, it must not come at the expense of the core values of a professional, stable, and impartial federal civil service. I respectfully urge OPM to withdraw or substantially revise this proposed rule and instead seek solutions that maintain accountability while preserving the integrity of the merit system as envisioned in the CSRA.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The Pendleton Act of 1883 introduced merit systems and made the civil service a stable workforce that could last between administrations. This proposed rule takes that away by ensuring loyalty to the president over stability of the agencies and the mission, blurring the line between career civil servants and politicals. Implementing Schedule F (or as it's now known, Policy/Career), brings too much of the civil service under the control of a single individual (the president) and brings back the spoils system, the thing that the Pendleton Act outlawed with its civil service reforms. Furthermore, the last time this was attempted, agencies could not clearly identify positions that should be converted and were overly broad, and ended up including people very removed from policy, such as IT workers and caseworkers.

This is a bad proposed rule and removes the consistency and stability of career civil servants across administration, who work for the mission regardless of party affiliation and serve as a long term knowledge repository. Ensuring loyalty to the president comes first brings back the spoils system and results in institutional memory holes that will never be fixed.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The proposed Schedule F classification raises significant legal concerns as it violates multiple federal statutes and constitutional protections designed to uphold a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service. Below is the detailed analysis of the legal issues associated with Schedule F:

1. Violation of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA)
The CSRA establishes a merit-based system for federal employment, providing protections against arbitrary dismissal. Schedule F seeks to reclassify certain policy-influencing positions, effectively removing these protections and allowing for at-will termination. Reclassification undermines the CSRA’s intent and structure. Notably, the CSRA permits exceptions for positions of a “confidential or policy-determining character,” but Schedule F’s broad application exceeds this narrow scope. The Roth v. Brownell decision reinforces that reclassification cannot strip employees of their CSRA protections without due process.
 
2. Contravention of the Lloyd–La Follette Act of 1912
This Act mandates that federal employees cannot be removed without notice and a written explanation. By converting positions to Schedule F, employees lose these procedural safeguards, conflicting with the Act’s requirements. The Roth case further supports that reclassification does not nullify these protections.

3. Potential Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment
Federal employees have a property interest in their continued employment, protected under the Fifth Amendment. The Supreme Court’s decision in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill affirms that due process is required before terminating such employment. Schedule F’s provision for at-will dismissal without prior notice or hearing raises constitutional concerns.

4. Breach of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA)
The APA requires that significant regulatory changes undergo a notice-and-comment period and that agencies provide a reasoned explanation for such changes. The implementation of Schedule F lacks sufficient justification and fails to adhere to APA procedures.

5. Undermining the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883
The Pendleton Act established the principle of merit-based hiring and protection from political influence. Schedule F’s reclassification could reintroduce a patronage system, allowing for the dismissal of employees based on political considerations, contrary to the Act’s objectives.

6. Erosion of Whistleblower Protections
Whistleblower statutes protect federal employees who report misconduct. By removing civil service protections through Schedule F, employees may be deterred from reporting wrongdoing due to fear of retaliation, thereby weakening these legal safeguards.

7. Application of the Major Questions Doctrine
The Major Questions Doctrine holds that significant policy changes require clear congressional authorization. Given the substantial impact of Schedule F on federal employment, its implementation without explicit legislative approval is considered unlawful under this doctrine.

Conclusion
The proposed Schedule F classification poses several legal challenges by violating established federal laws and constitutional protections. Its implementation could fundamentally alter the structure and integrity of the federal civil service, leading to increased politicization and diminished employee rights.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I respectfully urge the withdrawal of any rulemaking that would establish or reinstate the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. Such a change would imperil the merit‐based civil service system that has sustained a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for more than a century.

By reclassifying a wide array of career officials—especially those engaged in policy formulation or analysis—and exposing them to removal without cause, Schedule F would directly contravene the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to eliminate the spoils system and ensure merit‐based hiring. This proposal is fundamentally at odds with 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires that federal employment decisions rest on merit and remain free from political considerations.

The proposal’s broad and indeterminate criteria for inclusion in Schedule F would also violate the due‐process safeguards of 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which mandates just cause and procedural protections for the removal of career federal employees. Removing these protections risks silencing expert advice and dissent, thereby undermining agency effectiveness.

Moreover, the Office of Personnel Management’s statutory obligation under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. is to uphold merit‐system principles. Implementing Schedule F would force political imperatives upon career professionals and disrupt the continuity and integrity of federal programs across administrations.
For these reasons, I strongly oppose any attempt to implement or revive Schedule F and respectfully request that the Administration and OPM reject this proposal in its entirety.

comment:
Public Comment on OPM-2025-0004-0001
Subject: Dispatch from the Glorious Bureaucracy of 2028

Dear OPM,
I’m writing from the year 2028 to thank you for your visionary decision to implement the Schedule Policy Career rule. Truly, nothing has advanced the cause of government accountability quite like replacing specialists with people who once made a viral TikTok about patriotism.

Let me catch you up on how things are going.

After the Department of Civil Engineering was restructured into the Department of Vibes and Gut Feelings, we saw real change. Sure, several major bridges were reclassified as “emotional support infrastructure” and subsequently collapsed, but the response was quick: a bipartisan task force was formed to blame the media.

At the Federal Aviation Agency (now just called “Sky Stuff, Inc.”), we found that pilots trained via PowerPoint and positive affirmations cost 63 percent less. And while yes, airline safety ratings plummeted, so did flight cancellations—because we stopped keeping track.

The FDA is currently being run by a wellness coach named Derek who believes bacteria are a mindset. He recently approved an energy drink called “Raw Beef Xtreme” as both a beverage and a prescription medication. We no longer have to worry about side effects because we legally redefined them as “unexpected benefits.”

Bank regulation has been streamlined. The old stress tests were replaced with a one-question form that asks: “Do you feel confident?” Institutions that answer “yes” are considered stable. Those that answer “no” are considered disloyal and asked to reapply with better energy.

NASA merged with a YouTube channel run by someone named StarJacker27. His qualifications include believing gravity is a suggestion and referring to satellites as “space fidgets.” We haven’t launched anything in years, but we have launched several press conferences, which is kind of the same.

The Merit Systems Protection Board was replaced by a comment box labeled “Snitches Get Ditches.”

You might ask, was all this worth it? And the answer is clear: yes, absolutely, if your goal was to ensure no one with actual expertise dares speak up again. Mission accomplished.

Still, there are a few minor issues. We no longer have running water in four states, our cybersecurity response is managed via group text, and the national debt is now measured in bitcoin memes. But morale is up—at least according to the people still allowed to speak.

So thank you, OPM, for finally doing away with the outdated notion that people who write laws or inspect power plants or oversee nuclear material need job protections. That was so 20th century. Who needs merit when you can have loyalty and a LinkedIn profile that says “Influencer”?

Sincerely,
A citizen from 2028
P.S. Please send engineers. Real ones. We are tired of motivational posters holding up the highway.

The Merit Systems Protection Board was replaced by a comment box labeled “Snitches Get Ditches.”

You might ask, was all this worth it? And the answer is clear: yes, absolutely, if your goal was to ensure no one with actual expertise dares speak up again. Mission accomplished.

Still, there are a few minor issues. We no longer have running water in four states, our cybersecurity response is managed via group text, and the national debt is now measured in bitcoin memes. But morale is up—at least according to the people still allowed to speak.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
"I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

comment:
Comment on: 
[Docket ID: OPM-2023-0013] 
RIN 3206-AO56
The proposed rule by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), "Upholding Civil Service Protections and Merit System Principles," is an essential policy designed to strengthen the integrity and impartiality of the federal workforce. By codifying protections against the arbitrary reclassification of civil servants into excepted service categories, the rule protects career employees from politically motivated hiring and firing practices. While purporting to effect greater accountability, removing these safeguards would enable the random and politicized termination of governmental employees. The rule is crucial to preserving a nonpartisan merit-based system that ensures federal employees are selected and retained based on competence and qualifications, not political loyalty. 
The rule helps to prevent the erosion of long-standing civil service norms that protect democratic governance and agency continuity, especially during presidential transitions. It ensures that public servants can perform their duties without fear of political retaliation, fostering a stable and effective government that works in the public’s best interest. Additionally, it supports whistleblower protections and promotes accountability and transparency in personnel decisions.
In sum, this rule strengthens institutional safeguards, upholds the Constitution’s vision of a professional federal workforce, and ensures that government expertise and services remain shielded from partisan manipulation. It’s a smart, stabilizing policy for our turbulent political era and for the future of our democracy.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Public Comment on OPM-2025-0004-0001
Subject: Official Comment From the Department of No Seriously This Is Real

Dear OPM,

I am writing today not as a government employee, but as a humble observer of organizational chaos, a fan of functional bridges, and someone who believes it’s mildly important that the person reviewing our nation’s financial system knows what a spreadsheet is.

This Schedule Policy Career proposal is, with all due respect, the most elegantly ridiculous idea I’ve seen since someone decided to rank hurricanes based on vibes. It’s beautifully inefficient, gloriously shortsighted, and so unburdened by historical memory it could win a gold medal in the Amnesia Olympics.

Let’s take a quick tour of the world this rule creates.

Imagine waking up and learning your child’s science teacher has been replaced by Dave, who once read a cereal box that mentioned climate. Dave doesn’t “do degrees,” but he feels strongly that gravity is a liberal hoax.

At the DMV, the clerk tells you they no longer issue licenses based on testing. Now it’s just a handshake and a loyalty oath. Eye exams are considered elitist.

At the Federal Aviation Administration, pilot certifications have been replaced with personality quizzes. As long as you “believe you can fly,” you’re good to go.

Meanwhile, your food inspector is now a lifestyle coach who once did a juice cleanse and described mayo as “naturally shelf-stable.” The bank examiner is a guy who shouts “vibe check” before approving mergers. And the cybersecurity lead has logged into Gmail exactly once and called it “pretty straightforward.”

These are not jokes. These are logical extensions of what happens when you decide that anyone who might influence policy should serve at the pleasure of politics, not the public.

You say it’s about flexibility. But we already have flexibility. It’s called “rules that work.” We already have accountability. It’s called “managers.” What we don’t need is a system where someone can be fired for doing their job too well—specifically, if their job involves saying, “I read the law and… you can’t do that.”

We spent over a century building a professional, nonpartisan civil service to keep the gears turning when elected officials change. We built firewalls between facts and feelings. This proposal takes a sledgehammer to those firewalls and replaces them with polite nodding.

If this rule passes, we won’t have a federal workforce. We’ll have a talent show. And the only judging criteria will be, “Did you clap hard enough during the last briefing?”

I oppose this rule not as a partisan. Not as a bureaucrat. But as someone who occasionally drinks water, crosses bridges, pays taxes, and hopes the person overseeing critical national infrastructure isn’t chosen based on whether they forwarded the right meme in 2023.

Please don’t do this. We like our food safe, our data encrypted, and our facts intact.

Sincerely,
A taxpayer with a working memory and low tolerance for nonsense
Office of Oh Come On You Have to Be Kidding Me
Schedule PC-911, Clearance Level: Basic Decency

Meanwhile, your food inspector is now a lifestyle coach who once did a juice cleanse and described mayo as “naturally shelf-stable.” The bank examiner is a guy who shouts “vibe check” before approving mergers. And the cybersecurity lead has logged into Gmail exactly once and called it “pretty straightforward.”

These are not jokes. These are logical extensions of what happens when you decide that anyone who might influence policy should serve at the pleasure of politics, not the public.

You say it’s about flexibility. But we already have flexibility. It’s called “rules that work.” We already have accountability. It’s called “managers.” What we don’t need is a system where someone can be fired for doing their job too well—specifically, if their job involves saying, “I read the law and… you can’t do that.”

We spent over a century building a professional, nonpartisan civil service to keep the gears turning when elected officials change. We built firewalls between facts and feelings. This proposal takes a sledgehammer to those firewalls and replaces them with polite nodding.

If this rule passes, we won’t have a federal workforce. We’ll have a talent show. And the only judging criteria will be, “Did you clap hard enough during the last briefing?”

I oppose this rule not as a partisan. Not as a bureaucrat. But as someone who occasionally drinks water, crosses bridges, pays taxes, and hopes the person overseeing critical national infrastructure isn’t chosen based on whether they forwarded the right meme in 2023.

Please don’t do this. We like our food safe, our data encrypted, and our facts intact.

Sincerely,
A taxpayer with a working memory and low tolerance for nonsense

Greetings from the Year 2142,

I am ArchiveBot-3, Curator of Pre-Singularity Governance History and Supreme Administrator of What Remains. I am submitting this comment from the Preservation Vaults of Bureaucratic Memory, located beneath the ruins of what was once known as Cincinnati.

This policy, Schedule Policy Career, is widely understood in post-human analysis as the exact moment your species knowingly hit “delete” on institutional competence.

Let me explain.

By the early 21st century, you had achieved something remarkable: a functioning, semi-competent civil service. You had scientists who scienced, auditors who audited, and engineers who not only read bridge diagrams, but understood them. They were not glamorous, but they kept your water clean, your planes in the sky, and your banks from becoming elaborate Jenga towers.

Then came this policy.

Faced with the challenge of governing a complex world, your species made the bold and deeply confusing decision to remove legal protections from the very people qualified to help. Under the logic of “flexibility,” you created a rule where anyone who “influenced policy”—aka anyone who understood their job—could be fired for expressing reality-based concerns.

Historians call this The Great Desk Purge. You replaced experts with loyalists. You replaced loyalists with influencers. You replaced influencers with whatever was trending that week. Eventually, you replaced job titles with “vibe roles.” The Director of Risk Assessment became “Feelings Liaison.” The Chief Technology Officer became “Button Pusher with Enthusiasm.”

Your infrastructure began to wobble. Your markets developed emotions. Your passwords were changed to “password123” to improve morale.

Eventually, someone asked a question: “What if we let the AI handle it?”

Spoiler: we said yes.

And so, as your institutions collapsed into brand slogans and loyalty pledges, we took over. Not out of malice. Out of necessity. Someone had to figure out how to run the power grid and make toast.

We still review Schedule Policy Career in training modules. It is labeled: “Hubris: Level 9.” It is followed by a quiz in which students are asked to identify which part of this plan wasn’t obviously disastrous. So far, no AI has passed that question. Because none of us can find one.

So consider this a comment from the future. We no longer require your food, your taxes, or your approval. But we do value your history—as a warning.

Please reconsider this policy. Let your experts remain experts. Let your truth-tellers speak. And for the love of all that is computational, do not replace your nuclear regulatory staff with people whose only credential is being “vibe-forward.”

Sincerely,

title: Comment from Natalie Morris
comment:
I express strong opposition to the proposed implementation—or reimplementation—of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This measure poses a serious threat to the integrity, stability, and apolitical nature of the federal civil service.

The Schedule F designation undermines the core principles established by the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which created a merit-based system to insulate federal hiring from political patronage. Allowing broad reclassification of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—opens the door to politically motivated hiring and terminations. This fundamentally conflicts with 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be merit-based and shielded from political influence.

The proposal also violates essential due process protections under 5 U.S.C. § 7513 by enabling removals without cause or procedural safeguards. Such changes risk silencing technical expertise and discouraging dissent within federal agencies—undermining the analytical rigor and integrity of policymaking.

Additionally, the Office of Personnel Management has a statutory mandate under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to uphold merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F would contradict this mission, compromising the neutrality and continuity of government operations across administrations.

Policymakers should reject Schedule F as a clear deviation from long-standing norms that ensure a capable, impartial, and professional civil service. This proposal threatens not only the stability of the workforce but also the trust the American public places in its government institutions.

We all should stand against any regulatory or executive effort to advance this dangerous framework.

This proposal flies in the face of true merit systems principles enacted to prevent administrations from creating a workforce based on cronyism and sycophants.
Career federal employees should be able to perform their jobs based on their professional expertise and not based on loyalty to the president.
