title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Subject: Public Comment Opposing OPM Proposed Rule 2025-004


I write to express deep concern regarding OPM’s proposed rule (OPM-2025-004), which purports to enhance accountability within the civil service by creating a new employment category for certain policy-influencing roles. While accountability is an important goal, this rule risks politicizing the civil service and weakening the foundations of impartial governance that have served our democracy for over a century.

1. Threat to Civil Service Neutrality:
The rule creates ambiguity around what constitutes a “policy-influencing” position, and opens the door to discretionary and potentially politically motivated removals. This fundamentally undermines the principle of a nonpartisan civil service. Career federal employees must be able to offer honest, evidence-based guidance to leadership—regardless of political climate—without fear of reprisal.

2. Chilling Effect on Public Servants:
The prospect of being removed for subjective or ideologically driven reasons may deter federal employees from providing critical but politically inconvenient information. This chilling effect degrades policy-making and weakens government oversight functions.

3. Risk to Institutional Knowledge and Continuity:
Federal employees in policy-advisory roles often possess years—sometimes decades—of institutional knowledge. Sweeping removals in these roles threaten the long-term effectiveness of agencies, especially in complex fields like national security, public health, and regulatory enforcement.

4. Erosion of Public Trust:
The public depends on a professional and apolitical federal workforce. Perceptions of increased political interference in the civil service will diminish public confidence in government decisions, enforcement actions, and policy execution.

5. Disincentive for Talent Recruitment and Retention:
This rule may deter talented individuals from pursuing public service, knowing their careers could hinge not on performance or ethics, but on political alignment. That is antithetical to the merit-based ideals OPM is charged with upholding.

In summary, while efforts to improve government performance are commendable, this rule appears to prioritize political loyalty over professional excellence and nonpartisan service. I urge OPM to withdraw or substantially revise this rule to ensure it aligns with the foundational values of merit, neutrality, and long-term institutional resilience.

title: Comment from Joan Jefferies
comment:
I am firmly opposed to any effort to create or revive the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees.  This proposal would strike at the heart of the merit‐based civil service system that has ensured a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce since the Pendleton Act was passed in 1883.

Under that landmark reform, hiring and promotion in the federal government became tied to objective measures of competence rather than political allegiance.  By designating large swaths of policy analysts, program managers, inspectors and other career staff as “Schedule F,” the administration could strip them of long-standing due-process protections, reclassify them at will, and terminate them without cause—effectively reinstating the very spoils-system abuses that Pendleton and the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) were meant to abolish.  Such a move would conflict directly with 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires that federal employment decisions rest solely on merit and be insulated from partisan pressure.

Moreover, resurrecting Schedule F would undermine institutional knowledge and discourage top-flight professionals from entering or remaining in public service.  It would chill candid analysis and weaken agencies’ ability to offer neutral, data-driven advice, ultimately eroding public trust in government.  In 2020, an executive order first established Schedule F; it was revoked the following year in recognition of these risks.  Reviving it now would not only reverse that sound judgment but also set a dangerous precedent for politicized personnel management in every corner of the federal establishment.

title: Comment from Liz Donohue
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.



The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Joe Vallino
comment:
I have several concern regarding the rule for the functioning of Science in the US as follows:
1. Potential for Political Interference: If scientific positions are classified as "policy-influencing," scientists could be more vulnerable to removal for disagreeing with or challenging political agendas. This could lead to scientists tailoring their findings or recommendations to align with the administration's views, rather than presenting objective, evidence-based conclusions.

2. Decreased Scientific Integrity: The fear of reprisal could discourage scientists from conducting or publishing research that contradicts the prevailing political narrative. This could undermine scientific integrity and lead to the suppression or manipulation of scientific information.

3. Loss of Expertise and Institutional Knowledge: Frequent turnover in scientific positions due to at-will employment could result in a loss of expertise and institutional knowledge within government agencies. This could hinder long-term research projects, data collection, and the development of effective science-based policies.

4. Reduced Scientific Independence: If scientists are more easily removed for their views or findings, their independence could be compromised. This could lead to a decline in public trust in government science and the perception that scientific decisions are being driven by politics rather than evidence.

5. Difficulty Attracting and Retaining Top Scientists: The uncertainty and potential for political interference associated with at-will employment could make it more difficult for government agencies to attract and retain top scientists. This could weaken the scientific capacity of the government and its ability to address critical issues.

comment: This is very interesting. Every comment I browsed, maybe 20+, was against this regulation. And every comment except one, played the anti Trump, DOGE and Musk cards. title: Comment from W.  McTavish
comment:
I am writing to comment on proposed rule OPM 2025-0004 "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service".

This proposed rule does not clearly identify the scope of Federal employees that would be impacted. I recommend that the authors revise the proposed rule to clearly identify the policy-making roles that would be subject to this proposed rule. Once the subject policy-making roles are identified, I recommend completing an impact assessment. An impact assessment should identify the number of positions impacted by Federal agency to determine the positive or negative outcomes of the proposed scope. These should be publicly considered when proposing this dramatic change to the makeup of the civil service. 

Second, this proposed rule seeks to bypass the regular performance review process used in the civil service. I recommend that the authors of this proposed rule examine the current performance appraisal process to identify changes that would make it easier for all federal staff to be held accountable. This proposed rule only alters the performance and accountability procedures for a subset of Federal employees that are in policy-making roles, giving this proposal limited impact to the civil service in general. I recommend that the authors of this proposed rule identify ways to streamline the accountability for poor performance throughout the Federal government through the regular performance review process.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
A bedrock principle of our republic is a professional and nonpartisan civil service, a system carefully constructed on merit since the passage of the Pendleton Act in 1883. The proposed "Schedule F" classification poses a significant threat to this enduring foundation. By potentially allowing the reclassification and dismissal without cause of a broad spectrum of career civil servants, particularly those engaged in crucial policy formulation and analysis, this initiative opens a dangerous pathway for political considerations to unduly influence hiring and firing decisions. This directly contravenes the spirit and letter of 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which clearly mandates that federal employment decisions must be rooted in merit-based principles, shielded from the vagaries of political influence.

Furthermore, the imprecise and expansive criteria for inclusion under "Schedule F" raise serious concerns regarding the fundamental due process protections currently afforded to career federal employees under 5 U.S.C. § 7513. These established safeguards require just cause and adherence to procedural fairness before the removal of dedicated public servants. To strip potentially thousands of these individuals of such essential protections not only weakens the mechanisms of accountability within our government but also creates a chilling effect on the willingness of experts to offer candid advice and dissenting opinions, ultimately undermining the operational effectiveness of our governmental institutions.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) also bears a statutory responsibility, as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., to vigorously support and uphold the principles of the merit system. The implementation of "Schedule F" stands in direct contradiction to this vital statutory mission. It would subject career professionals to undue political pressures, thereby compromising the integrity and the essential continuity of federal programs that serve the American people across different administrations.

In conclusion, the "Schedule F" proposal represents a grave danger to the fundamental tenets of sound governance, the cherished independence of our civil service, and the overarching rule of law. It is my considered and firm conviction that the current administration and the Office of Personnel Management must resolutely reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this ill-conceived and potentially damaging classification.

title: Comment from Shobi Martin
comment:
I completely and strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. 

It would take away a merit based system that ensures a federal government full of workers that are nonpartisan and held to high standards. 
The creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883. It allows partisan politics to hold sway over our federal government workforce instead of a merit based since it allows a large number of federal employees, many who have served our government for their entire career, to be fired without cause. Politically motivated terminations and hiring will be on the table if this is allowed which is incredibly detrimental to the functioning of our federal government particularly in regards to those who make and analyze policy. 

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F directly contradicts this. It allows political pressure to be a deciding factor in how one performs their job instead of one’s aptitude, causing employees to be ineffectual due to their fear of being terminated without cause. (The cause being they do not align politically with the decision makers.)


The vague criteria for inclusion in schedule F violates due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 751 which can only lead to a more ineffective government as it encourages a lack of accountability, transparency, and discourages alternative points of view which are needed for a successful federal government in a democracy.

To sum it up, the Schedule F proposal is antithetical to maintaining a well functioning, non partisan, federal government where employees can do their jobs without fear of reprisal due to differences in thought or belief. Please reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive Schedule F, I implore you.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The proposed rule changes are completely misguided. In order to have an accountable and responsive civil service, civil service employees need to have the assurance that they will not lose their job at the whim of a supervisor. Employees working/living under the perceived threat of losing their jobs at any moment for any reason will inherently be distracted from completing their work efficiently. If an employee is not doing their job effectively, it is the managements responsibility to document any insufficiencies, provide warnings and opportunities for the employee to improve. Termination of employee should require documented proof that they are not doing their job. Management should not be able to terminate an employee because they do not like an individual for any reason, specifically for race, gender, age, ethnicity, or political views. The proposed rule change would allow such abuses to occur. 

In addition, civil service employees involved in grantmaking decisions should not be considered policymakers. Their job is to listen to the communities in need and assess in good faith what are the most pressing needs (i.e. drafting funding opportunity announcements), evaluating the grants without bias, and recommending grant recipients without bias. This process should be driven by needs not policy. The proposed rule changes would allow current civil service employees to be replaced with policymakers. Policymakers making these decisions leads to sycophants and corruption. Decisions will no longer be made in the best interest of the communities, but in the best interest of the administration. No matter your political swaying, the proposed rule changes are bad for the country and should not be implemented.

title: Comment from William Krahe
comment:
This partisan rule would result in a regrettable return to the spoils system and decimate the institutional knowledge critical to maintaining a functioning government that serves the American people.

I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am writing to express my strongest opposition to the Office of Personnel Management's proposed rule implementing Executive Order 14171, which would create a new "Schedule Policy/Career" in the excepted service and remove procedural protections and appeal rights for employees designated as occupying "policy-influencing" positions.

This proposed rule would significantly disrupt the functioning and effectiveness of the federal government in several critical ways:
1.	Compromising the Merit System and Operational Continuity: The proposed changes undermine foundational merit principles while threatening the professional, non-partisan civil service that ensures continuity across administrations. Career civil servants with institutional knowledge are essential for maintaining operations during transitions of power.
2.	Creating Workforce Instability and Loss of Expertise: At-will employment for "policy-influencing" positions would lead to increased turnover and loss of specialized knowledge. This destabilization would make it difficult to recruit and retain talented professionals essential to government operations.
3.	Undermining Due Process and Employee Morale: Eliminating MSPB appeal rights removes crucial protections that ensure merit-based employment decisions. This change would significantly damage morale across agencies, as employees face uncertainty about reclassification of their positions.
4.	Expanding Political Influence Through Vague Criteria: The term "policy-influencing" is inherently broad and subject to interpretation. Without clear criteria, this designation could be applied to numerous career positions, extending far beyond roles that genuinely involve policy formulation, leading to increased politicization of government operations.
5.	Inhibiting Expert Advice and Professional Judgment: Federal employees must provide candid professional advice without fear of summary dismissal. This rule would discourage career employees from offering their best professional judgment when it might contradict political preferences, undermining evidence-based decision-making across government.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Subject: Opposition to Proposed Rule OPM-2025-0004-0001 – Preservation of Civil Service Protections

I am writing to express my opposition to the proposed rule OPM-2025-0004-0001, which seeks to rescind protections established under the "Upholding Civil Service Protections and Merit System Principles" rule. This proposal aims to reinstate provisions similar to those in Executive Order 13957, potentially allowing for the reclassification of certain federal positions into a new excepted service schedule without the standard merit-based hiring and removal protections.

Concerns:

Erosion of Merit-Based Principles: The merit system is foundational to a competent and impartial federal workforce. Allowing broad reclassification of positions undermines these principles, potentially leading to appointments based on political affiliation rather than qualifications.​

Threat to Nonpartisan Expertise: Federal employees provide critical, nonpartisan expertise essential for informed policymaking. Reclassifying positions could suppress dissenting opinions and discourage honest analysis, impairing the government's ability to serve the public effectively.​

Legal and Administrative Challenges: The previous implementation of similar provisions under EO 13957 faced significant legal scrutiny and was ultimately revoked. Reintroducing such measures may lead to renewed legal challenges, causing instability and uncertainty within federal agencies.​

Negative Impact on Employee Morale: The potential for arbitrary reclassification and removal can demoralize the federal workforce, leading to decreased productivity and challenges in attracting and retaining skilled professionals.​

Conclusion:

Maintaining a merit-based civil service is crucial for the effective and impartial functioning of our government. I urge OPM to reconsider this proposed rule and uphold the protections that ensure a fair and competent federal workforce.

Thank you for considering my comments.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Subject: Opposition to OPM-2025-0004-0001 – Protect Civil Service Independence from Political Loyalty Tests

I write in strong opposition to the proposed rule OPM-2025-0004-0001, which would open the door to reintroducing mechanisms similar to those under former Executive Order 13957. This rule risks politicizing the federal workforce by allowing the reclassification of career civil servants into a category of employees who can be hired and fired without the usual merit-based protections.

At the heart of my concern is the threat this proposal poses to the independence and integrity of the civil service. If enacted, the rule would enable the executive branch to subject career officials to implicit or explicit loyalty tests, requiring alignment with the political priorities of the President rather than adherence to law, science, and the public interest.

Key Issues:

Encouraging Loyalty over Expertise:
The reclassification of positions removes critical due process protections, effectively allowing political appointees to dismiss civil servants based on perceived loyalty rather than competence or adherence to ethical obligations. This creates a chilling effect where employees may feel pressured to conform politically to avoid retaliation or termination.

Undermining Nonpartisan Governance:
Civil servants are obligated to serve the public and uphold the Constitution—not to serve the personal or political interests of any one administration. Weakening their independence by tying job security to political loyalty erodes the public’s trust in an impartial government.

Historical Precedent and Rejection:
A similar framework was widely criticized and ultimately revoked in the past because it posed such an obvious risk to democratic norms and accountable governance. Reintroducing this idea—especially after its rejection—threatens to normalize a dangerous precedent.

Stability and Continuity in Government:
Our nation depends on a stable, professional civil service that can endure across administrations. Allowing widespread reclassification risks turning expert agencies into echo chambers, reducing their ability to provide honest, evidence-based policy guidance.

Conclusion:

This proposed rule is not about reform—it is about control. We must not allow a return to a system where public servants are forced to pass political loyalty tests to keep their jobs. I urge OPM to preserve the integrity of the civil service by withdrawing this proposal and upholding the principles of impartial, merit-based government employment.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

comment: This rule is very concerning. title: Comment from Jon Davies
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

As a government supervisor, there are multiple tools and processes at my disposal to reprimand or remove an employee. Further, there are similar tools and process to ensure that all individuals get a fair shake. Getting rid of the something that forces a merit-based system seems counter intuitive to the current administrations policies.

The creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

Increased Political Patronage: Hiring could be based on political loyalty rather than qualifications, leading to cronyism and favoritism.

We would moving backwards to early 1900s approach with this policy change.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I write this comment to express strong opposition to any proposed rule or executive action that would reintroduce Schedule F or any equivalent classification that would return civil servants to an "at-will" title. Central to my concern is such that this measure poses a major threat to the institutional independence of federal agencies and the long-standing tradition of a nonpartisan, expert-driven civil service. Federal agencies are delegated this power to remain unbiased in regards to political pressures and, should this proposed rule pass, Schedule F would erode the separation between elected leadership and the professional workforce that carries out the law. This is not merely an administrative change, but rather a fundamental shift in how government power is distributed and exercised, and should be strongly considered when voting on this rule. 

The role agencies play is that of an informed and responsible institution that should be distanced from partisan influence and focused directly on the security and wellbeing of both democracy and the government's constituents. Though the NPRM cites that lack of administrative power over federal agencies undermines democracy by "[enabling] government power to be wielded without accountability to the voters or their elected representatives", this is a misleading interpretation of the role agencies play in our government. As discussed in Administrative Procedures as Instruments of Political Control, when any administration gains the ability to easily intervene and control the decisions of bureaucratic agencies, it opens the door for these agencies to be used for political gain (McCubbins et al.). This threatens the safeguards in place to protect against corruption and manipulation, compromising the independence of the bureaucracy and its ability to act impartially in the public interest. Passing this rule would set a precedent that would both diminish the credibility of our federal agencies and threaten our democracy as a whole.

title: Comment from S Majors
comment:
I am writing to comment on proposed rule OPM 2025-0004 "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service".

I oppose this proposed rule on the grounds that 1) the definition of an applicable "policy-making" position is not clear and that 2) this proposal could focus instead on reforming the current performance appraisal process to ensure accountability for all federal staff.

If this proposed rule were truly focusing on performance for those in policy-making positions it would succinctly identify the exact positions this proposed rule applies to. Instead this proposal leaves "policy-making positions" open to interpretation while also sweeping all managers in as policy-making positions. Most managers in the federal government are not policy-making. Most positions in the government are not policy-making. This proposed rule is fundamentally flawed, as it does not seek to solve performance concerns.

Considering the alternatives that the authors could have proposed to address performance and accountability concerns, the only logical conclusion is that this proposed rule is politically based and meant to undermine civil service protections to control the actions of federal employees. Considering that all federal employees are charged with upholding the constitution and abiding by laws, why is this proposal necessary?

Civil service protections exist to ensure that federal staff are non-partisan. Federal staff need civil service protections to ensure that they protect the constitution and laws at all costs. Eroding civil service protections means that federal employees will have no recourse if or when they are asked to complete illegal tasks.

If this proposed rule is adopted as is it will be very clear to the US and the world that the US government is no longer to be trusted, as all of its staff's livelihoods are at the whim of a despot.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I oppose the implementation of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that ensures a nonpartisan federal workforce.

Enacting Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing, which violates 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8). If federal employees served at the whim of the political party in charge, priorities and workforce would change every 4-8 years, resulting in the ability to get anything done, and fear of doing anything considered out of step with leadership. How does the government propose maintaining the nonpartisan nature of the federal workforce under Schedule F?

Additionally, the vague criteria in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. So many of the people who work for the government are driven by their mission to serve. Enacting this rule will ensure that many of these talented, passionate people will choose careers in “safer” environments. The workforce we end up with will be those who serve a specific leader or agenda. Is there a plan to continue to recruit and safeguard highly qualified and motivated individuals to join federal service under Schedule F?

I urge the administration and OPM to reject implementation of this dangerous rule.

title: Comment from Mathew Marsh
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement this dangerous classification.
Also, please remember, these are American lives and livelihoods that will be affected by this change. Federal workers love their country and the American people who they serve. They should ultimately be accountable to the American people and should follow the laws of the land, not the preferences of one administration or the other. They should not fear losing their jobs for obeying the laws of the United States.

rationale: The comment explicitly opposes the proposed rule by emphasizing the need for decisions to be free from political influence, which aligns with concerns about politicization. Additionally, it highlights the importance of expertise, indicating a concern for institutional knowledge loss.
themes: Politicization concerns, Institutional knowledge loss

title: Comment from John Smith
comment:
This order wrongly applies employment rules for political appointees and at-will workers to career staff; deprives federal employees of due process rights that they were promised when they were hired; and ignores Office of Personnel Management regulations.  It is a dangerous step backward to a political spoils system that Congress expressly rejected 142 years ago. 

Staff of the federal agencies secure the nation, safeguard the public health, promote economic growth and protect consumers from fraud. Their jobs require training and expertise in their chosen field so as to provide the best possible service to all Americans, not passing a political loyalty test.

The Office of Personnel Management established additional safeguards for employees in the event of an executive action like this and those regulations became final in May 2024.  This order has no right to circumvent these regulations.

Civil servants should be focused on their tasks to deliver for the American people and must be protected from arbitrary replacement based on political ideologies, and the corruption that can result from reclassifying them in the same category as political appointees.  The expertise of career civil servants has value and the regulations protecting their employment must not be stripped away to make places for political loyalists who may lack the same expertise and experience of the staff they replace.  The partisan interference that this order advocates in the staffing of federal agencies must be blocked in order to not impair the functioning of these agencies.   Career Federal employees deserve better protection against this treatment and stability in their careers, and they have it in OPM regulations that this order ignores.  The American people deserve agencies staffed with experienced workers that work for their benefit.  This order would strip away their job security and open up the likelihood of being replaced by less qualified staff in order to assert politcal control over the functioning of these agencies.

Opposing this is foundational to how we can ensure that the government delivers for people.  That is what a democracy is about.

title: Comment from Mary  AtKisson
comment:
[Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004]
Program officers at federal agencies that oversee research grantmaking should not be political appointees. The structures established in the creation of the United State's great scientific federal agencies have resulted in America's technological supremacy. The program officers that create grant solicitations and oversee peer review have been dedicated to funding outstanding science, regardless of any current political winds. They have been able to do so because they are experts in the relevant scientific fields. Political appointees with no true scientific training would, frankly, miss the actual impact of proposed work through ignorance. Plus, the open approach to science has led to discoveries that a political appointee would have blocked. Most of the current weight loss drugs owe their existence to an attempt to understand a lizard's biology with regulating blood sugar. Making program officers purely political appointees will not have a positive impact on American technical supremacy, and will have a direct negative impact on the economy.

title: Comment from J B
comment:
I am firmly against the introduction or reinstatement of the “Schedule F” employment classification for federal workers. This proposal endangers the merit-based civil service system that has sustained a competent, impartial federal workforce for more than a hundred years.

At its core, Schedule F directly conflicts with the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was designed to eliminate the patronage system and promote merit-based hiring in the federal government. By allowing a significant number of career civil servants—especially those engaged in policy work—to be reclassified and potentially dismissed without just cause, Schedule F paves the way for politically driven employment decisions. This contradicts the principle of a politically neutral civil service, as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires that hiring and firing decisions be based on merit, not political affiliation.

Additionally, the overly broad and ambiguous standards for placing employees under Schedule F run afoul of the due process protections in 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which guarantees cause and fair procedures before career employees can be removed. Taking away these safeguards from thousands of public servants would not only erode accountability but could also discourage candid advice and dissent, weakening the effectiveness of federal agencies.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), governed by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., has a legal duty to uphold the merit system principles. Instituting Schedule F would undermine this mandate and expose federal employees to excessive political pressure, ultimately jeopardizing the stability and impartiality of government programs from one administration to the next.

In summary, Schedule F represents a serious threat to the core values of good governance, civil service neutrality, and the rule of law. I call on the administration and OPM to reject any move to establish or revive this harmful classification.

title: Comment from Jeremie Fish
comment: The federal civil service examination was put in place precisely because the executive branch (primarily through Andrew Jackson, but others as well) abused the civil service by putting in place only people loyal to them (the spoils system). Removing highly qualified employees at the whim of the executive, and allowing said executive to appoint unqualified individuals simply because of their loyalty will severely impact the civil service's ability to perform its stated duties. The proposed change will endanger us in a variety of ways, including our current health and well being, as well as our future health and well being (the impact on science will be tremendously negative if unqualified individuals are allowed to lead scientific agencies). The civil service is meant to serve us, the American people, not the executive branch specifically. It is the American people, not the president, who pay the civil service salaries and thus these positions must have a level of independence from the executive branch in order to ensure that they are serving the people and not only the president. It is impossible for the executive to be an expert in all things, and the civil service plays an important role in keeping the executive from making terrible mistakes in areas in which they have no expertise. Additionally the civil service ensures continuity between different administrations for the American people, allowing the federal government to continue to operate smoothly and effectively during transitional periods. Such stability will be endangered by the proposed rule changes!

title: Comment from Aurelia Honerkamp-Smith
comment:
I object to the proposed rule change. The current procedures are in place precisely to prevent politically-motivated interference with scientific prioritization and direction. The result of this change will be loss of crucial expertise, destruction of objectivity, and compromised, low-quality research. Throughout the 138 year history of the NIH, every other administration has recognized the immense value that high-quality scientific research provides to the United States and has allowed it to continue organizing world-class medical and technological progress, independently. So keep your gross hands off of it. 

Also it is disingenuous to claim that the change will increase "democratic responsiveness" when the current president won office with a very narrow margin and his approval ratings are currently dropping. Interfering with science research is extremely unpopular with the people of the United States.

title: Comment from Jo J
comment:
I am a former Federal Employee and have grave concerns over these suggested changes.

1. Undermines Merit-Based System: Creating such a Schedule Policy/Career for policy-influencing career positions risks politicizing career civil service roles. By prioritizing "accountability to the President" over merit-based principles, it could erode the impartiality and professionalism of the federal workforce, weakening public trust in government institutions.

2. Reduces Employee Protections: Amending 5 CFR parts 752 and 432 to exclude Schedule Policy/Career employees from the procedural protections under chapters 75 and 43 removes critical safeguards against arbitrary adverse actions or performance-based removals. This could lead to unfair treatment, reduced morale, and increased vulnerability to political pressure.

3. Creates Confusion in Service Classification: The amendments to 5 CFR parts 212 and 213 blur the lines between competitive and excepted service by allowing employees to retain competitive status while in excepted positions. This creates administrative complexity, inconsistency in hiring and management practices, and many potential legal disputes over employee rights and status.

4. Reverses Recent Reforms Without Justification: Rescinding the April 2024 rule’s amendments (e.g., clarifying policy-influencing positions as non-career and imposing procedural requirements) without clear evidence of the failure of those amendments undermines regulatory stability. It disregards the rationale behind those reforms, which likely aimed to protect career employees from politicization.

5. Risks Inconsistent Hiring Practices: Allowing positions moved to Schedule Policy/Career to retain their prior hiring procedures (competitive or excepted) creates a patchwork system. This could lead to inequities in recruitment, hinder workforce mobility, and complicate compliance with federal hiring standards.

In total, these changes could destabilize the federal workforce, erode protections, and prioritize political influence over merit, ultimately harming government efficiency and public trust.  Should I ever decide to return to the public service workforce, would I be subject to a test of my Knowledge, Skills and Abilities? Or, instead, would I be subject to a political questionnaire?  Would my job and all of my work be terminated and erased with every new administration (as is currently being done with cancer research via the cancellation of research programs that the US taxpayers have already authorized)?

This series of suggested changes destabilizes my confidence in the effectiveness of the US Government in addition to any confidence in job security in returning to the Federal workforce.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
"I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I write in strong opposition to the proposed rule to reinstate Schedule F, as outlined in Docket ID OPM-2025-0004. This proposal poses a fundamental threat to the integrity, professionalism, and nonpartisan nature of the federal civil service.

Schedule F undermines merit-based protections that have long safeguarded the U.S. government from political interference. Reclassifying federal employees into a new "excepted service" status—without the due process protections afforded to career civil servants—risks transforming a professional workforce into one subject to political loyalty tests. Such a move would erode the foundational principles of neutrality and competence in public service.

Federal employees are entrusted with carrying out the laws of the land, guided not by partisan allegiance but by expertise, ethics, and public interest. Schedule F would:
* Open the door to arbitrary dismissal of experienced career professionals.
* Create a chilling effect on federal employees who raise concerns or dissent in good faith.
* Weaken institutional knowledge by incentivizing turnover based on political cycles.
* Damage public trust in agencies that must remain neutral, data-driven, and accountable to all citizens—regardless of political affiliation.

These concerns are not hypothetical. The previous creation of Schedule F in 2020 sparked widespread alarm across agencies and was met with bipartisan condemnation. The merit system principles laid out in 5 U.S.C. § 2301 emphasize fair and open competition, equal opportunity, and protection from political coercion. Reinstating Schedule F would directly contradict these statutory principles.

As a concerned citizen, I urge the Office of Personnel Management to withdraw this proposal and instead work to strengthen—not weaken—the merit-based civil service system that has served our country with honor and professionalism for over a century.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comment.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The proposed Schedule F rule under Docket OPM-2025-0004 undermines the principles of merit-based civil service and threatens the stability of the federal workforce. By reclassifying certain policy-influencing positions as "at-will," the rule removes critical protections that ensure employees can perform their duties without fear of political retaliation or undue influence2.
This rule risks politicizing the federal workforce, as it allows for the dismissal of employees based on subjective criteria rather than objective performance metrics. Such a shift could lead to a loss of institutional knowledge and expertise, as experienced professionals may be replaced by individuals chosen for their political alignment rather than their qualifications.
Moreover, the rule could discourage talented individuals from pursuing careers in public service. The lack of job security and the potential for arbitrary dismissal create an environment of uncertainty, making federal positions less attractive to skilled professionals.
The federal workforce is designed to serve the public interest, not partisan agendas. By eroding the safeguards that protect civil servants, the Schedule F rule compromises the integrity and effectiveness of government operations. It is essential to uphold the principles of fairness, accountability, and nonpartisanship in the civil service to ensure that the government can effectively serve its citizens.

title: Comment from Andrew Dougherty
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from A.  A.
comment:
Here's why many citizens on both sides of the political discretion, are critical of this proposed rule, drawing on legal and policy arguments:
1. Undermining Merit-Based Hiring and Promotion:
 * Legal Basis: The Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) (5 U.S.C. § 2301 et seq.) established a merit-based system for federal employment, emphasizing qualifications, competence, and political neutrality. This system aims to prevent patronage and ensure a skilled and professional civil service.
 * The Issue with Proposed Schedule F: Critics argue that creating a new Schedule F, which would reclassify certain federal employees as "excepted service" and remove some of their civil service protections, could open the door to political influence in hiring and firing. Positions could be filled based on political affiliation or loyalty rather than merit, potentially leading to a less qualified and less effective workforce.
 * Source: The principles of merit-based employment are central to the CSRA and have been consistently upheld in legal interpretations and government policy. The proposed Schedule F is seen by many as a direct challenge to these principles.
2. Diminishing Job Security and Due Process Rights:
 * Legal Basis: Current federal employees in the competitive service have certain due process rights, including protections against arbitrary dismissal and the right to appeal adverse actions (5 U.S.C. § 7513). These protections are designed to ensure fairness and prevent politically motivated removals.
 * The Issue with Proposed Schedule F: Reclassifying employees under a new Schedule F could significantly weaken or eliminate these job security protections. Employees in these positions might be easier to fire without cause, potentially leading to a chilling effect on their willingness to provide candid advice or challenge political directives. This could also lead to instability and a loss of institutional knowledge within federal agencies.
 * Source: The procedural protections afforded to competitive service employees are well-established in federal law and regulations. The proposed Schedule F seeks to create a category of employees with fewer such protections.
3. Potential for Political Purges and Instability:
 * Policy Argument: Opponents fear that a new Schedule F could be used by future administrations to conduct politically motivated purges of the federal workforce, replacing experienced professionals with individuals more aligned with the current political agenda. This could disrupt the continuity of government operations and erode public trust in the impartiality of federal agencies.
 * Source: Historical examples of political patronage systems and the rationale behind the CSRA highlight the risks associated with weakening merit-based protections.
4. Negative Impact on Federal Workforce Expertise and Effectiveness:
 * Policy Argument: A federal workforce subject to political volatility and reduced job security could experience lower morale, increased turnover, and difficulty attracting and retaining highly qualified individuals. The loss of experienced professionals could undermine the expertise and effectiveness of federal agencies in carrying out their critical missions.
 * Source: Studies on public sector management and the importance of a stable and professional civil service support the idea that weakening job security can negatively impact workforce quality and organizational performance.
5. Circumventing Congressional Intent:
 * Legal/Policy Argument: Some argue that creating a broad new excepted service category like Schedule F could be seen as an attempt by the executive branch to circumvent the intent of Congress in establishing the competitive service and its protections. Changes to the civil service system have historically involved legislative action.
 * Source: The history of civil service reform in the U.S. demonstrates the significant role of Congress in shaping the structure and protections of the federal workforce.
In Conclusion (Regarding OPM-2025-0004):
The proposed Schedule F under OPM-2025-0004 is considered a "terrible idea" by many due to its potential to:
 * Politicize the federal workforce.
 * Undermine merit-based principles.
 * Weaken job security and due process rights for federal employees.
 * Create instability and the risk of political purges.
 * Harm the expertise and effectiveness of federal agencies.
 * Potentially circumvent congressional intent regarding the civil service system.
These concerns are rooted in legal frameworks like the Civil Service Reform Act and policy considerations regarding the importance of a nonpartisan, professional, and stable federal workforce for effective governance. The debate surrounding this proposed rule is likely to continue, with significant implications for the future of the U.S. civil service.

title: Comment from Jon Citizen
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Jackie W
comment:
Comment on Proposed Rule: OPM-2025-0004
Federal Register Citation: 89 FR 20562
Agency: Office of Personnel Management (OPM)
Subject: Amendment to Civil Service Rule VI—Excepted Service

I write in strong opposition to the proposed rule (OPM-2025-0004), specifically the amendments described in Section I (“Background”) and Section II (“Proposed Rule”), beginning on page 20563 of the Federal Register notice. The implementation of this rule would significantly politicize the federal civil service and compromise the impartial execution of official duties—particularly in critical areas such as the oversight and administration of scientific research funding.

This proposed rule risks inserting subjective, ideological criteria into the hiring and classification process, thereby undermining the objectivity necessary for positions that steward federal research funding. These roles must remain insulated from political influence to ensure that federal support for science is administered equitably and based solely on merit and evidence. Political loyalty or alignment should never substitute for scientific qualifications, as doing so would erode the credibility and integrity of publicly funded research programs.

Furthermore, current federal civil service regulations already enforce merit system principles, as codified in 5 U.S.C. § 2301. These principles safeguard against political interference by mandating fair and competitive hiring based on ability and qualifications. The proposed changes would subvert this established framework, allowing increased partisanship in civil service roles and weakening the public trust in government decision-making, particularly in scientific and technical domains.

For these reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw the proposed rule and reaffirm the federal government’s current commitment to nonpartisan, merit-based hiring practices that protect the integrity of civil service and preserve the objectivity essential to scientific research administration.

title: Comment from Benjamin Rainey
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Elizabeth Brand
comment: I oppose this proposed rule. First, it is illegal under the Civil Service Reform Act. Second, it runs the risk of creating an entire civil service beholden to the President, rather than to the rule of law or the mission of the agency they serve. Employees faced with the idea of being fired for not complying with an order, no matter how illegal, would be significantly more likely to commit illegal, potentially criminal, acts for fear of losing their jobs if they do not. No employee should work under fear of a retaliatory firing for attempts to serve the American people honorably. Third, there is a reason that political appointees and civil servants are differentiated between in status. This proposed rule would essentially transform all federal employees to political appointees, subject to be fired at will by the executive. A federal workforce unable to properly serve their agency mission for fear of reprisal, or unable to stand up to illegal orders, or unable to defend their agency's mission from attack is not an effective workforce. I fear that this proposed rule would lead to a lawless executive and an ineffective civil service, both changes that would have sweeping consequences that would take years, if not decades, to fix.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Allison James
comment: I oppose this regulation change. Making managerial and policy staff fireable at-will will greatly decrease the productivity, reliability, and functioning of the federal government. It’s been months and not all agencies have a director yet, and how long will it take if an incoming administration fires all at will managerial employees upon taking office to replace them? Every administration could see a new set of employees that need to learn the processes which takes time and effort from the existing staff to teach them. It means a loss of experience and a loss of continuity. We have a reliable, not corrupt bureaucracy that has allowed companies to trust in the stability of America. This would further imperil that stability and trust. Government employees join government to spend their career there serving the public. They serve the public whichever party is in power. They do so with the understanding that as long as they perform satisfactorily, they have job security. Without job security, there is no reason for employee loyalty. I oppose this regulation as it would damage the government’s ability to effectively serve the public and attract talent that is dedicated to the mission.

title: Comment from Anne O'Dell
comment:
I am vehemently opposed to reclassification of federal employees to the Schedule F proposal. 

I am opposed for the following reasons:

Case law and previous legislation has prevented this action due to the documented history and propensity for abuse. The Pendelton Civil Service Reform Act was enabled in 1883 to prevent a 'spoils system' that benefitted loyalists. It also established requirements for Merit Based hiring and selection. Additionally, 5 USC § 7513 provides the legal requirement of due process based on cause for removal of federal employees. OPM is also bound to 5 USC § 1101 to support Merit system principles. This proposal contradicts the legal requirement OPM is mandated to support. 

In summary, this proposal fails to address the underlying procedural failures and promotes a system of governance that does not value established laws. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any changes to reclassification of federal employees to Schedule F or similar rules.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: This proposed change would be especially problematic for federal employees. Changing management to Schedule F would make those positions at will for any current or future administration.  This would discourage any federal employee from considering a management position due to the job instability. Most management positions in federal service are not directly related to policy and simply enact regulation and the tasks or projects that the current administration wants to focus on. Furthermore, this would lead to detrimental disruptions in federal agencies being able to serve the American people and the goals of the various programs. Management is typically a GS-13 or higher. Attaining this GS level takes several years, or at least 10 years to even be considered for a GS-13 and above. Thus a majority of staff do not have this GS level. If management was changed to schedule F and subsequently fired, it is very likely that no one will be able to take their position. Any signatures or internal review would not happen and progress would stagnate. I ask of our policy makers to explain how this proposal has any chance of benefiting federal workers ability to serve the government and our country.

title: Comment from Fiona Kearns
comment: I am a postdoctoral scholar working in a laboratory located within one of the top research universities in the world. Decreasing protections for civil servants, as would be the case if Schedule F initiative were enacted would be greatly detrimental to the continuance of excellent and rigorous science, for which the United States is known worldwide. Civil Servants -- like those within the NIH, NSF, DoD, DOE, NASA, NWS, NOAA, FDA, USDA, etc -- have dedicated their lives to the continual function and efficiency of our government and we should be eternally grateful for their service. The replacement of civil servants with political appointees would be wholly inefficient and cause incredible disruptions to many elements of USGov including but not limited to scientific innovation through research universities. Politics aside, replacing civil servants with political appointees would require incredible amounts of onboarding and training, slowing down government proceedings. Additionally, the institutionalized knowledge that each civil servant provides is not simply replaceable and much of that knowledge will be lost with the firing of current civil servants. Increased onboarding and training, as well as knowledge loss, will represent a huge amount of time and monetary strain on our government to simply maintain procedures which we already have which are working smoothly at this point. Furthermore, enacting of a Schedule F initiative could be considered a dramatic step in the direction of fascism and at the very least considered a demonstration of government overreach. I urge all government officials to fight against the Schedule F initiative and preserve what level of government efficiency we have remaining.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from S L
comment:
As a federal employee commenting in my personal capacity, I strongly oppose the proposed rule. This policy would represent an unprecedented increase in the politicization of the federal workforce, threatening the integrity and effectiveness of the civil service. This rule is not about poor performance. This is about greed and power for a few people while hurting hard working Americans like me and my co-workers who show up everyday and work hard even under great stress and fear for the future of our jobs and security of our families.

I work on scientific research aimed at improving clean air and clean water for all Americans. This work is grounded in evidence, guided by public health priorities, and intended to serve everyone—regardless of political affiliation. The ability to carry out this mission depends on a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service that values expertise and insulates scientific integrity from political pressures.

Reintroducing Schedule F would predictably undermine performance and accountability in the federal government by allowing for the removal of career professionals based on perceived political loyalty rather than objective qualifications or job performance. It would discourage innovation, suppress informed decision-making, and erode trust in public institutions.

This rule also poses a serious threat to core democratic values, including transparency and the rule of law. A politicized workforce risks silencing dissent, marginalizing science, and compromising the impartial implementation of policies that affect the health and well-being of millions of Americans.

I urge you to reject this rule and instead uphold the principles that have long protected the professionalism, independence, and stability of our federal institutions.
